description:
Such a fun activity on a Sunday! So much green grass sound to sprawl out and enjoy an afternoon. Transportation here is super easy and accessible with the presidigo buses which operate free on the weekends! 

This is a super family friendly event but can be enjoyed by all ages. There are TONS of food options to choose from so it's definitely something you will want to keep returning to and try a new vendor. I got the vermicelli from the Vietnamese truck at the very end and it was delicious.

As a vegetarian there are tons of options given the vast array of food trucks available and you will find almost every cuisine as well.
author: Rachel K.

description:
Beautiful location, great food, few lines.

Just a very well run food event.  Will come back.
author: Troy S.

description:
On Sundays from 11am-4pm, Presidio has an event where food trucks come to serve their delicious food. There is also bars and music arrangements as well. In the same park area, there is the Walt Disney house for those who like to tour. For individuals that like scenery, there is a beautiful view of the bay at the park. Parking is very difficult if you don't arrive early. We had to park outside of the Presidio entrance and walk all the way down to the park itself. There were plenty of hiking and running trails if you wanted to check them out.

Lines are numerous for the more popular food trucks such as Hotwings. However, you don't have to buy food from the trucks, you can always bring some picnic food. I saw many families there with their own food, saw one family with KFC! Its a great place for families and kickbacks, as well as, work functions. If you're ever in the city, this place is a must for Sundays.
author: Carter D.

description:
What a concept! I'm not sure how long Presidio Picnic has been a thing, but I came for the first time back in April. The sun was shining, a little bit of wind, but it was still a beautiful day for a picnic. 

Dogs are welcome, it's a great time to just kick it with the homies and grab some seriously good grub. The grass is lined with food trucks from near and far in the bay...I tried Senor Sisig for the very first time (I know, slacking) and Hot Bird fried chicken. The food trucks that share their delicious eats rotate every weekend! So it'd be worth it to visit whenever you can. 

Parking can be a hassle, lucky you if you snag a free spot. But there are lots where you can pay an hourly fee/all day parking that are just a short walk to the picnic site. 

Bring a few blankets to sit on, your own dranks, maybe a speaker that has volume strong enough just for your little area. 

A few people go around doing a $ polaroid service, which I thought was a nice touch. Because not everyone owns polaroid cameras, so if you are willing to buy one of your group - you'll have a small token of remembrance. 

Definitely check their website to see dates and if there are any special things happening!
author: Melanie B.

description:
2018 Presdio Picnic is every Sunday (Mar 18 - Oct 18); Hrs: 11am- 4pm
 
When the sun is out and there are clear blue skies, there's no better way to spend a lazy Sunday afternoon soaking in the sun, picnicking with friends, and scouting out the best food from the widespread selection of food trucks & stands. It's family & dog friendly so bring the whole crew!

Show up early especially if you have a larger group as it can get pretty packed and you don't want to end up sitting next to the food truck where there's a lot of foot traffic. For an open lawn, it's definitely cleaner and nicer to lay on compared to Dolores Park. People bring everything from yoga mats, blankets, camping chairs, Lamzac air loungers, umbrellas, and even tents. There are a few picnic tables but those tend to be taken up rather quickly. While sunny.. it does get a bit breezy from time to time so do bring a light sweater in addition to your shades & lots of sunscreen.

As for food.. bring some picnic food if you'd like or just go from food truck to food truck trying everything that looks delicious. There's a wide variety of food options enough including wings, ceviche, chowder, acai bowls, baked goods, ice cream and cuisines ranging from Mexican, Vietnamese, Filipino, Korean, Mediterranean, etc. There's something for everyone whether you're craving an elote, want to crack your own coconut juice or get a savory muffin from Craftsman & Wolves. I'm still baffled by how that soft boiled egg is cooked inside of the muffin!

The portable restrooms located by the parking lot are rather clean.. there were about 5-6 stalls in the ladies room so the wait wasn't too bad. Parking is metered (yes, even on Sunday) so you might be better off grabbing an Uber.
author: Ruby C.

description:
The best way to spend your Sunday with family and friends on a sunny day in San Francisco! We were visiting from Honolulu and our friends invited us to join them for a day at the Presidio for a food truck picnic. We took a Lyft to the park and were blown away by the number of people sprawled out on the lush green lawn with blankets, towels and chairs. I loved how many families with small children were there enjoying the sunshine and fresh air. 

I was impressed by the organization of the event which consisted of food booths, food trucks and multiple cocktail bars on the lawn. A wide array of food choices from Asian to Italian to dessert! Our group shared a pork belly plate lunch, hot chicken sandwich, ice cream and bloody mary's which put the Funday in our Sunday!
author: Emi H.

description:
A great way to spend your Sunday with friends, family, and significant other! You've got huge crowds of people chilling with their beach blankets, tents, and chairs listening to live music with tons of food options. And did I mention the view? How can you beat the waterfront and bridge view?

Parking isn't bad, we parked by the bathrooms for free, but it can be pretty limited. They've got portapotties on the green and is walking distance from actual bathrooms. 

It's probably the best Off the Grid event in regards to size. You've got lots of spaces to claim since it's an open field and there are enough vendors so that the lines aren't ridiculous.
author: Patty B.

description: This is by far the best OTG location. How can you beat the world class view as you lounge on the grass all day? I can't imagine a better lazy Sunday in the sun... and even when Karl shows up I can turn that frown upside down with a mango rose. Music, drinks, games, there's something for everyone, including kids and pets. Feel free to bring your own picnic - but it's almost a shame with the likes of Senor Sisig, A16, Del Popolo, Craftsman and Wolves, and the list goes on...
author: Cristina S.

description: Went here on a Sunday morning during Fleet Week.  Family had a great time.  Food was good and crowd was very polite.  Blue Angels were awesome too. Would love to go back again.
author: Bruce T.

description:
After hosting a dinner party at home for 7 people on Easter Eve, I wasn't going to host another party or cook on Easter. I decided the hubby and I will just spend our Easter at Off the Grid's Presidio Picnic. It was a warm sunny day in San Francisco, so the picnic idea couldn't have been more perfect. We brought our camp chairs and picnic blanket, and parked ourselves on the lawn with an amazing view of the Bay which was dotted with sailboats and kite surfers. 

Presidio Picnic is the best OTG event and on Easter the attendance was almost to capacity. That huge lawn was filled with couples, families, and small and large groups of friends. People brought their dogs too. Make sure to bring a hat, and camp or beach chairs or a picnic blanket if you're gonna stay a while. People also brought their own or rented tents for shade from OTG. 

There were lots of great food vendors that day, but we only got food from 4 vendors throughout the 4 hours that we were there.  We started with a plate of fried chicken from the Wing Wing Fried Chicken booth which we shared. Omg that was the best fried chicken I've had in a while! The hubby described it as flawless. All 4 pieces (wing, thigh, drumstick, breast) were moist, flavorful and perfectly seasoned. I was so surprised the breast was moist too. The chicken was crunchy without being heavily breaded. It was actually light. 

An hour later, we each had a plate of the Lechon with rice and salad, and some lumpia from The Jeepney Guy. The lechon skin was crunchy and melt in your mouth goodness. That plate was enough to keep us satiated for a while. For dessert, we shared the Cookies and Cream sundae from Bi-Rite! It was just enough satisfy our sweet tooth. 

Presidio Picnic has a bar if you need some libations to go with your food. You can get beer, wine, Bloody Mary, Margaritas and Mimosas. I got a Margarita and it was really good. It's a little pricey at $12 but hey it's convenient. 

If you want to get a good spot on the lawn and parking, get there early! The lawn filled up nicely after noon or so. The fancy port a potties were really clean, and the compost, recycling and trash bins were regularly replaced to prevent overflow. This is a very well run event, so I would definitely come back again for a picnic. I can't think of a better way to relax and people watch on a warm Sunday afternoon!
author: Hazel C.

description: We came to Presidio for the first time and it's nice to see people in the park. There's music, kids playing with their dogs and playing mini soccer. There's a lot of food trucks. It's hard to pick one because all of their food  looks good and there's a lot of choices. Finally, I got the korean chicken with kimchi and green onion and my kids got the grilled cheese. Before going here, we went to see the Wood line nearby.
author: Judith S.

description:
Been coming here for OTG for a while now. Some food vendors have changed year to year, a few staples like Del Popolo are still around, but it's still pretty much the same. A few dessert options, fried chicken, burritos, fries, meh. Good news is they've added two refreshingly different trucks: Ruru serving fruit/granola bowls and light smoothies, and  Bini's Kitchen with Nepalese momos.

People bring their kids, dogs, picnic set-up, or just stroll through like us looking for good eats. Lines get fairly long during peak times, so it's best if you come with a friend or a few to stand in multiple lines then find a spot to gather and feast.

It's super windy from the offshore winds but it's nice to stroll toward Chrissy Field and the Golden Gate Bridge.
author: Lindsey C.

description:
Cool spot for a picnic on a Sunday! 

Pros: amazing vibe, good food (Off the grid), picnic, clean restroom

Cons: parking, expensive food
author: Kenneth T.

description:
This is my most favorite Off the Grid event. Imagine... Big open space covered in nice green luscious grass, while being surrounded with tent/truck vendors offering you endless of food choices to enjoy your picnic on a Sunday morning. If that doesn't get you excited, I don't know what will.

My girlfriend and I went this past Sunday to enjoy some nice sun and good food. Good food and sun there were, but it was windy and cold. That didn't stop us from enjoying what they had to offer for that day.

Ok, here's the long list of the food we had that day. We ordered Rice Bowl with Korean BBQ from Bombzies BBQ and yes it was the bomb! We also had the Señor Sisig Burrito and Sisig Nachos from Señor Sisig. I've had them before but for some reason it wasn't as good this time around. Don't get me wrong tho, it was still good. We also went for the Oreo Mini Donuts by Hookt and it'll for sure will get you hooked. That didn't stop us from ordering The Rebel, a couple Valrhona Chocolate Cake Donut, and Vanilla Glazed Donut with Biscotti Crumbs from Craftsman and Wolves. Everything was really good especially the chocolate cake donut. Yes.. Yes.. I know. We ordered a lot. It's hard not to get a lot when you have all these good food around you. I'd eat everything if only it's humanly possible.

If you haven't experienced Presidio Picnic, you are missing out a lot. You don't want to miss out on the picnic that everybody is talking about, all the awesome food, the activities, and just enjoying the company of others on a picnic day. OH! For dog owners, don't forget to bring them along. There are a lot of dogs with their families who are enjoying this event as well.
author: Dennis M.

description:
My favorite thing to do on a Sunday afternoon. It's best to get there before 1pm because it gets super crowded after that! 

Such a fun outing every Sunday! Ring your own food and have a picnic or buy from one of the many food trucks, although lines sometimes get long!
author: Bethany M.

description:
Now that the rain is gone and people are ready for some sunshine, we can finally eat and picnic outside!! If you're looking for a family friendly and mellow spot to post up on a Sunday. I've been attending this picnic for many years now and it keeps getting better every year with more amazing food vendors and beverage companies. 

My go to food vendor is wing wings which is serving up some amazing fried chicken and biscuits. They also give you a side of pickles but, I buy an additional side as they are delicious. As far as drinks go, there's a great beverage vendor in the middle of the mall which I think is run by the folks at Rye in the tenderloin. They are mixing up some great cocktails and have affordable beer/wine options if you forget to bring your own. 

Come here and see for yourself as it's always a great Sunday!!!
author: Benjamin F.

description:
The picnic is a great spot to get out and enjoy the weather with friends and family. Sure they've got tons of food trucks but just to come and relax on the grass is fun. 

In fact, I would recommend bringing your own food and drink. Otherwise you may be susceptible to some very long lines at the trucks and bar. The longer the line, the better the food but the longer the wait! 

My thought would be to bring your own food and then go try one thing as most of the serving sizes are small. 

The reason I love this spot is simply because it's a relaxing thing to do outside with folks on a Sunday afternoon. We got there pretty early to grab a spot on the northern side of the lawn. I realize people want to be closer to the food trucks but it gets super crowded around you and we wanted room to spread out. 

Ultimately your call but I would recommend the grass away from the trucks for more room.
author: Matt M.

description:
Yes yes yes! We ran into this event on a fluke since we were heading to the Disney museum in the presidio. We were wondering what all these people in the park were doing and we decided to check it out. Low and behold it's a foodie fest! There were tons of booths, vendors of all kinds, and food trucks. 

What I liked about this area is that everyone is welcomed and its free! People would bring their own chairs, blankets, food, toys, games, umbrella, and anything else to pass the time. There was also music. I definitely felt the love and a spirit of family just walking through the park. No ghettoness/no fights, just a big huge friendly gathering.

I decided to grab lunch at the longest food truck line Senor Sisig. Took 30 mins to get my sisig burrito, and it was worth it!

If you get a chance to visit, do visit! If you live in the area, you are so lucky!
author: Maria C.

description:
The Perfect place to have a "off the grid" food truck extravaganza.

I found this by total accident walking my dogs here. Hey what are all these cool bright red benches?? Why are all these cool food trucks lining up on Thursday afternoon?? Yeah I'm dense like that.

Welp I have been several times on Thursday evenings and Sunday afternoons and every single time has  been a pure delight: From the BBQ from Cochon Volant, Sam's chowder mobile, and Del Popolo pizza thing a ma giggy.....all excellent btw.

The vibe is very chill. People tend to be very low key and not too pushy. You can bring your own booze if you want ( well at least we have). 

Views of the bay are simply breathtaking. 

If you can find one of the big plastic red couches....use them....they are great.

Only thing I did not care for were the mixed drinks at the bar in the middle....small minus.

Check it out on a warm Indian summer day!!!
author: David G.

description:
LOVE LOVE LOVE this little gathering. There is nothing better than taking a walk along Chrissy field with your pup and then going around the  corner for a bite to eat at this picnic as you soak in the sunshine and lovely SF vibe. Grab a blanket, a book, your loved ones and chill out!

You can park for a small fee at the large parking lots adjacent to the lawn. 

I'll be taking advantage of this picnic as much as possible until it ends in mid October.
author: Susie O.

description:
Perfect place to spend your Sunday's! Spread out the picnic blanket & bring some games to play after eating. I would definitely check the weather before coming since it can be a hit or miss but the time we went was absolutely perfect: sunny and breezy. The best part besides the food, is getting to dog watch! Haha! So many cute doggies running around! 

There are plenty of food trucks to choose from. Señor Sisig was the truck with the longer line. We got there around 2:45pm and it seemed at that point people have already gotten their food so the lines were significantly shorter. Didn't get to try everything but will definitely come back soon!
author: Jasmine O.

description:
We came to the OTG Presidio Picinic on a whim, trying to escape the 100 degree weather of Santa Rosa.  It was a beautiful, clear blue day and it might've hit 80 during the peak of the afternoon!  View of the bay was the icing on the cake.

The grounds were pretty packed with friends, families, pets (including a cute pot bellied pig named Prosciutto) and kids. People were relaxing in lounge chairs, on picnic blankets, or straight on the grass.  Everywhere I looked, people seemed to be enjoying themselves.

The FOOD TRUCKS.  Oh gosh what a great collection of options.  We walked around before making our decisions and finally decided on a few "basic" choices.    Every time I saw someone with a grilled cheese sandwich walk past me, I felt the twinge to try it.  It seems so simple, a nod to childhood, but it sure did appeal. Hubby chose a wood-fired pizza, son tried Senor Sisiig's burrito, and the two of them finished off with some mini donuts.  We planned to try the garlic noodles, the empanadas and the Asian chicken skewers but our stomachs betrayed us.  Next time!   The longest lines were about a 15 minute wait.

Though this seems "simple", I found it very nice of OTG to provide a very large water station to fill your bottles.   The water was even cold. Nice!

I LOVED it.  I will be more prepared next time by bringing  a blanket and a couple chairs.  We could've easily stayed longer!
author: Heidi D.

description:
When people ask me what my favorite culinary experience is in San Francisco, I will often times not mention a restaurant (though Burma Superstar omg so good). Personally, one of my absolute favorite "food" things to do in the city is to visit the food trucks at Off The Grid; if I hear from friends that they've never experienced Bay Area OTG before, you bet I'm taking them there the next time I have a chance. 

If you have ever heard of OTG before, Off the Grid is the Bay Area's very own "food truck" experience. All throughout the Bay, OTG will have different vendors (trucks) circulating throughout. From Sunnyvale (where I live) to Fremont, there's always trucks during different times of the year. Personally, my favorite Off the Grid has and will always be the one in San Francisco's Fort Mason - basically, for around like most of the year except winter, there's a HUGE block party every Friday near the Marina. There's always at least 15-20 different food vendors with music playing. 

Recently, I was able to share my love for OTG with my girlfriend at Presidio's Off the Grid (Presidio Picnic). It was actually my first time here at the Presidio Picnic and so I was pretty stoked. If I'm correct, Presidio Off the Grid is every Sunday during brunch time for most of the year. As the name suggests, this OTG is right at the Presidio (basically a park area next to the Golden Gate Bridge). Unfortunately, parking here can be rough since EVERYONE comes out (be it for the food or just to chill). And doubly bad, SF charges you for parking here. Unlike at Fort Mason, in which you can actually park at the lot or park on the street (weekends free), it's like $1.5 per hour/$8 full day and there's no alternative. Make sure you put that ticket on the dash! Also, I recommend bringing a blanket so you can sit and snuggle. Maybe also be bold and bring a tent. 

While Fort Mason OTG is all about partying at night with strangers in close quarters, Presidio OTG is definitely the opposite: here, you have a HUGE space to roam around and the atmosphere is much more chill-especially with kids and more doges everywhere. Unfortunately, there's probably half the number of food vendors. I counted around 7-8 really substantial trucks/tents for food, whereas the rest served drinks. BUT, luckily there's always a good turnout for reputable vendors. For example, Senior Sisig (omg, get this please) was there, as well as El Sur (their Empanadas are to die for). We ended up getting a burrito from Sisig (so good) and tater tots from Jackrabbit (not bad for only $5).

The beautiful thing about Off the Grid (especially the ones in the city) is the community component that gets injected into the food. Everyone knows that the Bay has the best, well-rounded people. But how do you bring them all together? Through food! At every Off the Grid, I always meet the coolest people. The Presidio is definitely no different. It's perfect for all ages. For example, if you are a child, there's little game areas for people to meet. There's even a tent with people teaching you how to bike. There's EVERYTHING!

I have to give Presidio Picnic an "omg, I'd travel 2 hours for this." The experience is well worth it, especially if you are in the city for a day. Sure, there's plenty of amazing restaurants in SF, but there's few that really give you the "hands on" adventure that OTG does. If anything, come to Presidio Picnic for the view of the city and the calmness that is basking in the sun on nice grass!

Have fun and prosper, eat well and prosper!
author: Bryan W.

description: Best place for a variety of great foods, family and pets. Bring your chairs and doggy bags!
author: Narcissa M.

description: Wow! As out of towners here for the weekend, this was an unexpected surprise. We were on our way to the Disney museum and had no idea this was happening. My favorite experience was when I spontaneously joined the group doing yoga on the lawn. I didn't bring a mat but the teacher was welcoming and offered to loan me a mat, but the grass was soft and the sun was warm and the ocean breeze felt amazing as I stretched & worked my way to yoga bliss. Was impressed with all the different food choices & was sad I only had room to try food from a couple food trucks - I personally had the jeepney guy's lumpia and it was so good! The sangria from the drinks tent was delicious. That view of the water and the bridge is breathtaking. What a great way to spend an afternoon!
author: Kezia B.

description:
A typical Off the Grid food truck gathering with the chief advantage being its setting on a huge lawn at the Presidio that allows for great scenery. 

Because there's so much open space, the event can accommodate lots of people. There's a reasonable amount of paid parking all around, while getting here via public transit isn't necessarily a chore if you figure your way out via MUNI and the Presidio shuttles. 

All in all, a great way to have an urban picnic of sorts.
author: Vincent L.

description:
What a fun Easter Sunday!!
Foodies Heaven!
Arrived at 11:30 am, parking lot is 1/3 full. 
Pretty filled up an hour later. 
Parking rate is $1.50 per hour or $8 entire day. 

Bean bag toss in the middle of the lawn area. 
Kids loved the game. 
Clean restrooms in the Presidio Trust Building (with baby changing station ) and the Officers Club. 
Restrooms at the Walt Disney Museum is for customers only. 

Great selections of variety of food. 
Really enjoyed lechon Pork belly Bao from the Jeepney Guy - plate came with two large bao and a side salad, soooo good!  My daughter enjoyed a grilled cheese sandwich for the Grilled Cheeze Guy - she said it was the best grilled cheese sandwich she's ever had!

Perfect weather, scenic location and fantastic event for the entire family!
author: Da Wahine W.

description:
What Fun! Glad I tried this outdoors activity this Sunday!

We came here at about 2pm. Lots of people but we still found a great spot to spread our blanket and chill. We opted for different food options such as baby back ribs from Cochon Volant BBQ, pizza from Del popolo and empanadas (mushroom and spinach) from El Sur food trucks! The ribs weren't that impressive but the rest was fabulous. We also tried the mini donuts at the end which were ok.

Overall a great spot for picnic with family and friends. Very family friendly which is awesome. Strong winds here so come prepared and bring warm clothes :)
author: Heliana M.

description: Bring a blanket and a jacket and some friends and you're good! Love trying all the food trucks, but I especially love senior sisig and the mango rose for dessert. The views are beautiful and the atmosphere is cheerful and lively!
author: Madeline C.

description:
I've heard about Karl the fog long before I moved the SF, but seeing it over the Golden gate and white sail boats weaving in and out of it at the presidio park still took my breaths away.

The picnic is very well organized with lots of food, drink, and event varieties. Sorted trashes in easily accessible locations. I would go there every weekend if the weather permits. 

Tips:
1. Bring tent/umbrella/sunscreens. This area is very sunny and white people (such as my husband, love you baby), usually gets burned otherwise. 
2. Pack your own food/drink/snacks. The prices are borderline robbery even for SF. Ex: A small lobster roll is $20
3. If you go around peak hour (12-3), Do NOT attempt to try your luck with one of the parking lots next to the main parade ground (where the action is), you are not the first or last to think that way and will waste 20 mins trying to follow people going to their cars only to find that they are just grabbing a blanket. Try around YMCA. You have been warned.
author: Tata X.

description:
I've been here a few times and it's generally a nice place to hang out with friends. Here's the good & the bad:

Good:
 - when it's nice weather, it's nice to have an open area picnic where you can chill, with a nice view
 - lots of space
 - music, lively ambiance
 - many food options

Bad:
 - It's cold & windy AF usually. If it's burning hot in the middle of the city (like today), then coming out here is nice because it's like 10 degrees colder. Always ridiculously windy though.
 - CRAZY prices for food. I'm talking like $8 lemonades, $19 lobster rolls, $6 mango on a stick. Let that sink in. 1 MANGO. For $6. OK.
 - longggggg lines for food.

All in all if it's good weather, you got time to kill, and you have money to spend, this is a pretty chill place to hang out!
author: Betty M.

description:
Although it's been months since I've been back, Off The Grid: Fort Mason is one of my favorite ways to spend a Friday night.  It's a chill and low-key activity after a long week at work, there are lots of vendors and tasty treats to check out, and, perhaps most awesomely, it's great for dates!  Sure, it can get chilly, but who cares?  Just another reason to get cozy with your (potential) cuddle buddy.  ;)

Along those same lines, much like how OTG: FM is a great way to end the work week, OTG: Presidio Picnic is a terrific way to start the end of the weekend (that is, as terrific as "starting the end of the weekend" can be).  Occurring every Sunday during the summer and fall, Presidio Picnic may not be as large as OTG's signature event, but it's just as popular.

If you're familiar with any of OTG's pods/events, the list of vendors and food trucks might look somewhat familiar.  OTG staples like Curry Up Now and The Chairman may be absent, but the list of eateries is still extensive and varied - Grilled Cheez Guy, Del Popolo (pizza), Little Green Cyclo (Vietnamese), Crème Brulee Cart, El Porteno (empanadas), Nopalito (Mexican), The Whole Beast (BBQ), Reveille Coffee, Sam's Chowder Mobile, La Marcha (Spanish), and Slightly Skewed.  And those are just the ones I can remember!

While the food is obviously the biggest draw, what really makes this particular OTG event so awesome is its location.  Posted up on the grassy lawn at the Presidio's Main Post, there's really no other food truck meetup that can compare.  On a warm, sunny day, it's the perfect spot to lay out a blanket, soak up the sun, and take in that gorgeous view of the bay in the distance.  Toss in some delicious eats and drinks and you just might start hearing Maroon 5's "Sunday Morning" playing in the background.

As picturesque as the setting may be though, sadly, Presidio Picnic isn't perfect.  Yeah, it sucks having to pay for parking, but there's always Uber/Lyft/MUNI.  Rather, the real knock is the lack of line control.  Maybe it was just the combination of the gorgeous weather and it being the first Presidio Picnic of the year, but the lines got ridiculously long as the day went on.  Already bad on its own, yet even worse when they started to snake between people's picnic spots, making it tough on everyone (maybe create a buffer zone?).

All in all, FOUR AND A HALF STARS is about right, but I rounded down (sorry!).  Still, lines aside, Presidio Picnic is an awesome (and free!) way to start your Sunday Funday.  Good food, good times, and plenty of good vibes to go around.  Plus, with the handful of alcohol stands dotting the picnic area, you can get an early start on the drinking to forget that you probably have that deadline for work on Monday!

CHEERS!
author: Mike L.

description:
Thursday evenings are the best! 

It almost feels like the weekend when you get to have dinner here on Thursday night. Get there right at 5pm. Score a great parking spot but don't forget you need to pay until 6pm. 

We love all the trucks but here are some of my favs: 

- wine and beer, large selection and reasonably priced. The wine pour is nice and hefty! 

- Deaf pizza truck, perfect sized, fire roasted pizzas. Don't be that guy, read the letters and learn the sign before you get to the window. It's easy! 

- The Sweet Truck, cookies! Easy to eat on the go and baked perfectly. My daughter finishes the peanut butter ones before I'm done paying. 

What to bring: 
- WARM clothes (summer in SF is no joke)
- Blankets to sit on and for your lap 
- BYOB if that's your thing 
- Frisbee or fun lawn game that doesn't take up too much space 
- Cute and friendly dog if you happen to own one
- Cute and friendly kid if you happen to own one
author: Alison C.

description:
I LOVE Off The Grid events.  I sincerely believe that it's happenings like this that truly make the Bay Area so special! 

Last weekend I had several out of town visitors that opted out of the Pride Weekend festivities because they didn't feel like being in large crowds.  I suggested Picnic At the Presidio as something different to show our guests.  It was a huge hit!

The food trucks and stands are incredible.  There's a wide selection that is sure to please everyone.  For example, while I was waiting for wood-fired pizza I stepped over to the Vietnamese food truck for spring rolls.  When I came back to our picnic area my friend had ordered Indian comfort food for us all.  

Remember to bring a blanket, sunscreen, and BYOB.  There's a picnic bar area for specialty cocktails, wine, and beer.   There isn't much shade, so an umbrella or tent is also encouraged.  

Dogs are very welcome, but make sure to keep Fido on a leash.
author: Andrea H.

description:
Definitely ranks up there in top SF experiences!! The way this event was described to me was basically a "Bougie Dolores Park" . People bring tents, picnic blankets, lay bags, wine/coolers, and just chill here.

The weather was just gorgeous this past weekend and we packed up the dogs for Presidio! It's kind of a trek to get there when you don't have a car, but it's well worth the commute if you intend on spending the entire afternoon there. There was a DJ and it was a bit noisy, but I don't know many people that "go out for some peace and quiet" anyway...

A bunch of food options here - almost like a mini Outside Lands! Plus coffee truck, tons of drinks/cocktails, and some good snack items too. We opted for various loaded fries and some arepas! YUM!

Another plus - People LOVE dogs here! Unfortunately, Mochi loves little children not one bit. TONS and TONS of responsible parents here that have all conditioned their children to ASK FIRST and not to run up screaming with outstretched arms. A+ to all you parents!! Also an A+ event if you're trying to socialize your dog with other dogs or humans!

Minus one star only because it is so incredibly out of the way and difficult to get to...but if you have a car and have good parking juju - this might be the right spot for your Sunday funday!
author: Jennifer S.

description:
This is a cool spot to come on a nice day! I came here during fleet week and it was the perfect spot to relax and watch the blue angels. You get a little view of the GG bridge peaking through and the water. 

I appreciated the many good food trucks that provided something for everyone. The cocktails were also a plus :) a great spot to bring a group of friends. 

Only thing I didn't enjoy were the screaming kiddos and parents who were super checked out. A kid came up to my picnic, picked up my purse and threw it at my face.. then proceeded to do it over and over again. I would recommend choosing your picnic spot wisely and *away* from the kids.
author: Kelly F.

description: Cool concept. Decent food. Needs more bathrooms. More organization. Lines were all over the place and confusing.
author: Carter Q.

description: Great variety of food trucks, coffee, ice cream, etc. And fun music too! It's a great place to come with your friends, family, and especially dogs! The only problem is that there is NO shade. Unless you find a tree off to the side.
author: Daniel C.

description: Such a great place and location to spend your day outside. I usually come here on a weekend whenever I want to unwind with friends and family. I definitely prefer this place over Dolores Park since there's such a chill vibe and you get a great view of the golden gate bridge and the area is super clean. On a nice sunny day, you can also squeeze in a tanning sesh while you're at it =) There's also plenty of food options as well (legit food trucks) so you'll never get hungry!
author: Diane L.

description:
Sundays are our fun days and I usually like to go to Dolores Park, but we happened to stumble upon this happening one weekend and were very happy we did! They had a great selection of food trucks, multiple bars scattered throughout the lawn and some really cute spots to sit and hang out. It is FREE to attend, which is awesome, but food and drink prices were a little high for my liking, so BYO snacks if you're the frugal type. 

We were able to ride the bus to the presidio, so parking was no problem and we also got to explore other areas around by foot which was fun. I will definitely be back this summer with my picnic blanket.
author: Whitney Z.

description: We love hanging out here. Food is great with different food trucks and vendors to choose from. Parking is hard though...
author: Maricar D.

description: If I didn't already live in San Francisco, I would move here after coming to Presidio Picnic on a nice sunny day. Great food. Good people watching. Dogs. Ocean. Bridge.
author: Morris R.

description: Food trucks were lined up around the perimeter. View of the bay was beautiful. It was windy and cold this past Father'sDay. Recommend blankets for next time.
author: Suzette C.

description:
Great food truck event offering a variety of eats from pizza to sushi, ice cream vegetarian to bacon options for the carnivore foodies. Excellent for the entire family, day time shindig, groups, girls day out, couples quality time...whatever your vice.

It's free, open to the public and has the best view in town right off the marina. Seated in the heart of the Presidio where the grass is healthy & green, the skies are beautifully blue and sun shines in abundance. Bring a blanket to lay out, grab a tent for shade or tote your portable folding chair to enjoy the festivities, adult libations & awesome live entertainment in comfort. 

Can't beat the grid.
~Christy
author: Christy A.

description: The Presidio is great for picnics! They have an abundance of food trucks and food stands surrounding the park square, plenty of variety to choose from for your picnic snacking while listening to music from a DJ tent. I came here for a birthday party and was super satisfied with a crab roll. Do note that this place gets crowded, especially in the weekends, so come early to pick your spot! Also if you're coming on a particularly sunny day like we did, bring a hat, umbrella or setup a half tent dome to shield from the sun's rays. There are no shade trees surrounding majority of the park, so in peak afternoon on a hot day, it gets pretty hot!
author: Christine D.

description:
Hipsters may have ruined food trucks, but at least they can't ruin the Presidio Picnic. Don't get me wrong; I like a lot of things that hipsters like, such as overpriced coffee and claiming I liked bands before they were popular. (I'd like to point out now that I also liked making fun of hipsters before it was popular. And yelp. I was on yelp back when most people were still using zagat). But there was a time when food trucks provided a generous quantity of tasty if unhealthy food cheap. You know, the whole no real overhead discount? At the Presidio Picnic, you won't find a heaping plate of fried food for $5, however. Be prepared to pay $10 for a small bag of tiny zeppole (which horrified my Italian American friend), which could alternatively have bought almost two dozen Krispy Kreme or even three giant (even more hip) Johnny's donuts. 

But still, even if your belly feels a little unsatisfied, you can't beat that view. And this is one of those events that is equally attractive to tech bros (and gals), families with young kids, dog parents, and everyone else who finds a little fog refreshing. Parking is easy, although you do have to pay. 

And to return to those things that hipsters like: can we please get someone who sells hot coffee there next year? Philz, Blue Bottle, Red Whale, anyone?
author: Susan S.

description:
Enjoyed coming here on a rare sunny 75+ degree day in SF. All my favorite food trucks and tents were there and the atmosphere was great! Definitely very crowded and lots of kids/dogs. This is like the grad school of parks and Dolo is sort of like undergrad. 

We had zeppoles from Girl Friday that were TO DIE FOR! Seriously good! Get the dozen half n half and get the harissa dipping sauce and earl grey chocolate ganache. 

Nopalito tacos were a solid choice but way too expensive for two tacos.

Del popolo pizzas were delicious and worth every penny. One of the best items at the picnic! 

La Marcha patatas bravas were surprisingly my favorite bite of the day. I only got in their line because it was short and I was hungry but I was pleasantly surprised! 

We had Luciano's ice cream for dessert which was just okay (too sweet). Will try the shave ice at powder next time.

Overall, this is where I plan to be on any given (sunny) Sunday all summer long. Bring your appetite and a picnic blanket. I also brought a bottle of wine on an ice pack because the drinks are really expensive (though they are strong).
author: Semuteh F.

description:
heard about this a thousand years ago but visited for my first time on fleet week sunday

perfect weather
and a sick volkswagen beetle & bus convention in the parking lot
what a day

dogs everywhere so i accepted the fact that i'd be stepping in a bunch of hotmess... but it never happened - shoe bottoms stayed spotless. miracle!

interesting vendor mix with multiple ones that have been in my bookmarks forever

this otg seemed at a higher avg entree price point than other truckeries

put it this way: in recent weeks i spent...
$20+ for 3 dishes at eat real festival
$20 for 2 dishes at otg fort yayson
$30 for 4 dishes at lumpia palooza
$39 for 3 dishes at otg presidio

but what i ate here was slightly "high end" in comparison so it's ok

plus there was a ymca woodshop tent for kids. it's always great when non-art festivals randomly have something where people create. i saw a child sawing stuff up get your tim allen on young'n
author: Dan B.

description:
First, let me take a moment to give a shout out to the OTG people that make this awesomeness happen.

Thank you very much OTG peeps!

Every Sunday from April to October, this magic happens.  It looks daunting.  I mean, it can't be easy to execute all of this without a hitch, right?  But somehow you manage to get this party started & rolling smoothly.  What a sleek operation!  Fabulous food trucks all gathered together at the beautiful presidio, complete w a DJ & drinks like Mint Juleps & Singapore Slings...

How great is this?!

I've never actually met an OTG production I didn't like, but the Picnic at the Presidio holds a special spot in my heart.  

Maybe it's the view of the GG Bridge & the bay?

Maybe it's being surrounded by all the sheer presidioness?

Maybe it's the combination of the sunshine & the manicured lawns?

And the view?

I dunno really.

I just know that it's awesome.

Dogs & kids galore.  Great food.  There's even coffee for chrisakes.

On my last visit, here are the goods I made out with...

Zucchini Bread.  GF & organic!?

Zeppole.  The savory ones.  Bacon, herbs, parmesan.  With the sriracha dipping sauce.  DELICIOUS!

Fried chicken from Wing Wings.  SO SO GOOD!  Except for the fact that I think it could have used some salt, I must say this fried chicken is pretty stellar.  My man totally monopolized it.  We got the cole slaw to go w it.  It was fresh & light, w a bit of a spicy kick.  He loved it, but I'm just meh about coleslaw in general.

An Arnold Palmer to wash it all down with.

See that?  We got breakfast, lunch, & dinner.

What a great addition to summers in San Francisco.

I heart you Picnic at the Presidio.

5 stars all the way.
author: Veronica M.

description: I absolutely love Off The Grid. It's set it a beautiful picnic area with a amazing view of the bay for one. The arrangement of food trucks and stands all serve delicious food and it's great sampling a little of the best of each category of the food for all the stands and trucks. I consider going to Off The Grid one of the best things you can do on a Sunday if you got some time and want to eat delicious food.
author: John V.

description: I really love Picnic In the Park at Presidio by Off the Grid. It may really be my favorite Off the Grid event. I love it because you're at the beautiful presidio on Main Post Lawn with the most amazing view into the bay. The grass is lush, and so you have PLENTY OF SEATING! Be prepared, bring your towel/blankets and other goodies. There are plenty of vendors and variety to choose from, and a lot of them take credit cards. You can come with a group of people and appease anyone's diets, dislikes or likes. There's coffee, juice and dessert. There is also the bar! Dogs are welcome :) DJ playing music. It's a great place to just chill, hang out and catch up.
author: Vanessa K.

description:
COOL! Nothing like it in the City. This is such a great use of the Presidio space!

Came here on a Sunday afternoon for a picnic with some friends.

PARKING: Arrived around 12pm and there were still several street parking spots left. There is also a parking lot as well. $1.20/hr even on Sundays!

FOOD: There are both food trucks and food tents! Take your pick! Lots of food options and they have a beer/wine bar in the middle of the park.

SPACE: SOOO much space to grab a spot on the lawn and sit. Bring a blanket (the grass can get a little wet) and just lay around and enjoy some good food and company. Several people also bring their dogs too! Very chill space :)

MUSIC: They had a DJ at the Park as well (closer to the Bay side) and the closer you get, the louder it is. Pretty funny to see the 100 ft in front of the DJ was empty. Nobody wants to blow their eardrums out!

It can get a little windy sometimes and there are definitely people here who bring tents/umbrellas. I believe some days they have a vendor who rents out umbrellas/tents for you to use. Super handy!

Would definitely come back here another weekend - heard Thursdays are pretty fun too!
author: Wing L.

description:
Wonderful idea but too cold during the twilight Thursday off the grids. That can't be helped. Wearing a sweater and jacket over it AND a scarf will stil not be enough, and I thought I was prepared!
Sunday off the grid is lovely with music, more people, but you will have to spend more time looking for parking ..which will be father.. And then scramble to look for a seat to sit at. Unless you don't mind the grass. Bring a blanket to sit on!
author: Veranna N.

description:
Technically an out-of-tower review...

Cause Sacramento is so not the City, but in proximity, it's pretty damn close. I've been drooling over Off the Grid SF Instagram for a long time, but getting to the Presidio on a Sunday just hasn't been in the cards...

...until this past weekend. Luckily, we had brunch and diddle daddle around the City...then got hungry right in the middle of the PP. Thank goodness Yelp has this is a location, so I could get us there properly.

The parking wasn't awful, but we did find street parking fairly easy. But it looked full everywhere. We had to pay where we parked, but I did see some free parking.

The thing is, I wasn't amazing by the actually truck/restaurant offerings they had. But I was in awe of the set-up, they had a variety of type of food to try, but it was really the nice, fresh green grass to hang out on that made me happy. Also, their ability to have booze stations was pretty cool (even though we brought our own, tisk tisk)!

There's a pretty view if you walk a little more towards the water. At the back, you don't quite get the good bay view. Overall, the whole vibe and set-up is pretty cool. 

Even the restrooms were nice, well the larger one with three stalls. Inside it was clean and almost resembled a normal bathroom, which was much appreciated on my behalf. I will say be careful on getting there, an entitled jerk in a Porsche might almost run you over and then try to yell at you! But hey, just saying that may or may not happen ;)

Keepin' SF chill, one Sunday at a time...
author: Steph G.

description:
Turning this underutilized grassy space into a food truck gathering is genius. There's lots of space to lounge on the grass, so bring a towel. Grab some food, get a drink, have a seat, and enjoy the view! Mr. Joy and I just happened to discover Presidio Picnic by chance. We also happened to have blankets at the time, so we checked it out. Unfortunately, it was close to closing time, so there wasn't much we could try. 4PM on a Sunday seems rather early, in my opinion. 
There were a lot of trucks, so there was a big selection. All the usual names were there, but we just got a few bites from Chotto & Tout Sweet Patisserie, which were okay. I'd return on a warm day, but I'll have to remind myself to arrive earlier.
author: Joy W.

description:
Great place to come during the weekend! The ambience is awesome: just like a big backyard party with (infinite) delicious food options. There are SO MANY options to eat, one more delicious than the next- almost to the point that you wish you shared the 4 stomachs trait with cows just to try it all! I personally tried the arepas truck. Pretty solid and delicious arepas... and that is a BIG compliment from me considering I am a Venezuelan arepa snob. I also had some caribbean food and it was solid! So so good... According to my husband, they have the best pork sandwiches here too! It's cool because everyone can go their way and choose the food preference, and then reconvene and share the goodness.  
Some things we would like to try in the future: epic-looking ice-cream sandwiches and fruit cups, fire-oven pizza truck that looked REALLY good, and delicious-looking Peruvian food. 
Great place to bring kids, dogs, and a big group of friends. The only thing I wish they had is more seating/shaded areas to eat- but if grass/sun doesn't bother you its a nice place to come eat, chill with friends, and enjoy the community vibe of SF. I would recommend you to bring a blanket/tent and water! 
Last but not least, some of the cleanest bathroom stalls you can find in a park are here. Pretty impressed by this!
author: Maria B.

description:
PERFECT location for some fresh air, tasty food, and great scenery! Bring a blanket, some shades, to enjoy a day of awesome food and vitamin C! 

There was 15-20 food tents on one side of the lawn and 6-7 food trucks on the other side. There was a great variety of food, from savory to sweet, and from American to Indian or Asian, etc. 

There was a booth for the Three Twins, which is an ice cream brand, and I just had to try it! I got a scoop of MEXICAN CHOCOLATE ($4) in a cone and it was AMAZINGGGG! It had a hint of cinnamon, and the cone also tasted great. The only downside was that it melted pretty fast. I got an extra cup and dumped the entire scoop into it. They take both cash and credit card, so very convenient! 

The view was also breathe taking, since it is right next to the GG Bridge. It is also 10 minute walk away from the Palace of the Fine Arts, which has an amazing view also.
author: Wendy F.

description:
Soooo incredibly crowded.  Some of the lines were dozens deep.  Would not come back for the picnic part of this event.  No room to walk through, let alone set down a blanket.  Granted, we did arrive at noon.

I went for the YBike portion of the day, which my kid LOVED.  The YMCA staff was friendly for the most part and provided positive encouragement and tips.  

Parking was a bit rough, but found a little non-metered, no time limit area.
author: Terence L.

description:
I've lived in the area for several years, so I'm actually a bit ashamed to say that today was my first time at Off the Grid: Picnic at the Presidio. Mostly because it was awesome and clearly I've been missing out!

There was a DJ playing some good music, tons of food trucks/stands, wine/beer bars, and plenty of sunshine.

Not having been before, I wasn't sure what to expect. Thankfully I brought a blanket and some beers to meet up with my group of friends (ended up being perfect). Chilled for a couple of hours in the sun with a good group of people, good food, good drinks. Couldn't ask for a better end to the perfect SF weekend :)
author: Krista S.

description:
This is a great way and place to spend a sunny Sunday afternoon. I would recommend coming early as possible to get good parking and to avoid long food lines. 

I got there around 12 and spent 10-15 minutes looking for parking. We paid $6 for all-day parking which isn't bad at all. When we got there, the place was already packed. There are a lot of different food vendors and carts. I would recommend doing a walk through first of all the different food vendors before making a decision. :) 

Places I tried:

--Sugarfoot Grits: This place had one of the longest lines. I wanted to try the bacon, egg and cheese biscuit sandwich. I waited in line for about 20 minutes. When you place your order, you have to wait even longer for your food. I was kind of disappointed because 1) there is an additional wait time for you and it's pretty long, and 2) the biscuit sandwich was not worth the wait. I thought the biscuit sandwich would be the size of a "regular" biscuit...like the ones at KFC, Popeyes, or the Pillsbury store-bought biscuit dough. The sandwich was probably the size of half my palm and it really didn't taste anything special. Would not order this again.

Girl Friday: Tried this place for their lemon ricotta donuts! Half a dozen donuts with a sauce of your choosing for $5. These are sooo delicious. You can't really taste the ricotta, but it was a really good donut. Super fried and the earl grey chocolate ganache with sea salt dipping sauce was amazing.

Creme Brûlée Cart: Yum!! We tried the SF Gold creme brulée. They ran out of the chocolate cookie crumble, which is a topping that comes in the SF Gold, so we replaced it with graham cracker. I like this cart because it's different and the serving size is good. I would definitely try this. You can tell they use real vanilla beans because you can see the black specks in the creme brûlée. 

Tips:
--Bring cash so that you can pay easily and get the line moving!
--Bring a blanket so you can have a picnic on the lawn!
--Bring an ice box/cooler with cold drinks. I think you can even bring your own alcohol. :O
--Bring a jacket because it can get windy.
author: Gina H.

description:
It may be partly cloudy but you'll get sunburned! Bring some sun screen!! We had a burst of 30 seconds of hot hot sun and I want to say...everyone in our group was pink/red and some even peeled the next day! 

Love the view. Love the weather. Love the experience. It gets crowded, so come before the lunch hour or slightly later. Music started towards the middle/end of the event, but it wasn't a big deal. Just wish we had enough time and space in our bellies for all of the food!
author: Karen L.

description:
Like what someone said on the Facebook page... 17k attendees but only 10 trucks today...? What...

List of food vendors today:
Doc's of the Bay (Truck) 
Cheese Gone Wild (Truck) 
The Crab Lab (Trailer)
El Sur (Truck)
Korean Bobcha (Truck)
Johnny Doughnuts (Truck)
The Boneyard (Truck) 
The Chairman (Truck) 
SAJJ (Truck) 
The Taco Guys (Truck) 

Got there around 6PM and had to park away from the main area. Good thing parking signs said 2HR parking 8AM - 6PM! Walked over to the place and saw many cute tents and people! Sooo San Franciscan haha. My friends & I checked out Korean Bobcha. The wait was about 50 minutes -__-" We got the Kimchi fries ($8.75) and Bulgogi Burrito ($9.75). The Kimchi fries were DELICIOUS! The Bulgogi Burrito tasted a little funny to me... Maybe because I ate burritos earlier this week that I wasn't feelin' this one, but I still ate it though.

Then we waited about and HOUR at the Falafel Shwarma place called SAJJ. We did see how long the line was and it only got longer as we waited in line - so there must be something great about this truck! I ordered the Falafel in Pita brea ($8)... The wait was so long that my friends and I immediately left the event around 9PM to go get some boba and eat there. I think the coldest made me not want to eat/ move anymore. But I enjoyed the falafel - just not sure if the hour wait was worth it though.
author: Nicole C.

description:
You really can't go wrong here...a well organized event where vendors with names to uphold serve you the food that you want. The little "timbits" are definitely worth getting, they gave us samples of their savory flavour, and that was worth getting in the future.

Sometimes the lines can get long at the popular booths/trucks, so definitely bring a friend and divide + conquer. It's also a dog friendly picnic. Possibly because of the location, the garbage was very well organized. Most places accept credit cards through square too so cash isn't mandatory.

Overall I only dock one star because the food made me really thirsty and was quite expensive for a meal.

I'd pair the picnic with a visit to the Walt Disney family museum across the street.
author: Alfonso C.

description:
A fun outing on a Sunday! Arrived at around 11:15-11:30 and there was still plenty of parking. I parked by the Presidio Bowling club north of the lawn and paid at the machine for parking, which was $1.50 per hour or $8 all day. 

Great for groups, lots of families and dogs. Lots of people but did not feel over crowded as we sat south of all the food.
author: Cynthia T.

description: Unlike other Off the Grid locations, this is not on cement but a lush lawn of beautiful green and ample parking throughout the Presidio. Would be good to do your homework before you head over as to which places you want to try as there are many food trucks and long lines. Alternatively, the group can separate and each tackle a line with multiple vendors. There is music available via a DJ, but the quality can vary depending on which day you visit. You can bring your own drinks and food, and it is strongly recommended that you bring blankets and chairs.
author: Kimberly H.

description:
Best food truck event ever! 

Today was my first time attending this event. My bf and I took the free PresidiGo shuttle from Embarcadero Transit Station straight to the event. Despite the mass of people and doggies, the lines were surprising not very long and went by extremely quickly. The food selection was huge and varied, the DJ played catchy music, and the entire lawn was filled with families who were either in tents, sprawled out on blankets, or running around playing games. It's very family-friendly, lively, and relaxing, with a beautiful view overlooking the entire Bay Area.

The premise kept clean throughout, with event workers educating and helping people sort their trash. Even the porta potties were beyond clean and quite fancy, where each stall was equipped with its own sink and napkin dispenser with a lot of room left to move around in. There were also ones equipped with up to 5 stalls in each trailer. Overall, the event was very well-planned and well-executed. 

But most importantly, the food was to die for. My favorite trucks were The Whole Beast (smoked corn on the cob), Fine and Rare (oyster po boy), and Girl Friday Zeppole (zeppole with vanilla bean creme fraiche dipping sauce). The prices weren't outrageous and the food was definitely gourmet, or at least with unexpected but delicious twists. For people looking to get a little tipsy, there is a alcoholic beverage station in the middle of the lawn. Like I said, this place is family-friendly, good for kids, adults, and pets.  

Note: bring blankets and jackets because the grass might be a little wet and the wind tends to pick up at times and temperature tends to drop, since it's by the water. Also bring cash, because some places are cash only (and trust me, you don't want to miss out on any food).

I will definitely be back to try even more foods.
author: Tiffany C.

description:
This is the Queen/King of Off The Grid events!! I've been to other OTG Events but nothing like this. I've heard a lot about this particular OTG and have wanted to go but never had the chance and once I saw that Sugarfoot Grits was going to be here and it was going to be warm that day, I made time to be here. 

They are located by the Presidio and right across the street from The Walt Disney Museum. Parking in this area was tricky and hard to find so I parked by Crissy Fields and walked (yes it was far, 1.3 miles to be exact). Once I got there I was taken aback, the grassy area where OTG was located was extremely spacious and beautiful. There were TONS of food booths, about 5 food trucks, a bar and a DJ. This seemed like a good festival/party. I walked around to check out all of the food booths even though I knew what I was there to get.

Some of the booths/trucks included Wing Wings, Creme Brûlée Cart, Fins on the Hoof and bubble bar just to name a few. I finally went to Sugarfoot Grits and ordered The Valencia ($10) which is cheese grits, organic greens and local "crispy" bacon. It was pure heaven, very much worth the walk and drive. I also went over to Wing Wings and had there fresh made fruit punch, it had a florescent pink color but was delicious, unlike any punch I've ever had. I sat on the grass to eat and drink while listening to the great music. It was so relaxing even though there were many people there.

If you are a big fan of OTG or just a foodie in general, this is a must and make sure to bring a blanket, football, frisbee or something to have more fun. It's perfect for the whole family to enjoy especially on a nice sunny day and you have a nice view of the Golden Gate Bridge.
author: Tiffany D.

description:
Probably the best way to get your food truck fix, with more food trucks, fewer lines, and often nicer weather than the evening events. The key is to get there early. At 11:20, parking was easy, lines were non-existent, and nothing was sold out. 

Lots of choices -arepas, goat tacos, sangria, pork belly sliders, ceviche, you name it.
author: Greg E.

description:
Food trucks with lobster, tacos, burgers, dessert, beer, etc. I love how they have a location for this event that brings people all over on Sundays to enjoy the food and the outdoors. What intrigued me besides attending an Off the Grid event is that it was dog friendly. So my bf and I brought our doggy here for a day of fun and relaxation. Located in Presidio Park, the giant lot in front of the Disney exhibit. I remember in high school I would have competitions here, it brought back memories.

Bring a picnic blanket (and a picnic, if you would like) and cash to purchase food ($12-25). I wish the food from the food trucks weren't so expensive. We got a Lobster Roll from one of the trucks (way too pricy for a small roll), delicious burger, Creme brûlée, beer. Yes, they sell alcoholic drinks there!

It's great for all ages. Bit of music, fun atmosphere. I recommend coming here with a picnic blanket, picnic, drinks, hat, sunglasses, dog (optional). I would love to go more frequently. It was a fun and memorable experience.
author: Winnie T.

description:
I used to live in Portland so I know a thing or two about food carts and master planned pods. This is nothing like that. This is a free form, hippie dippy love fest of all things food. There are food carts/trucks to be sure and there are also tents. There is a FULL bar in the center of the lawn; there is also an ATM (Good to know!) L and I did this as a recon mission. We weren't sure what we would need to bring and wanted to get the lay of the land. 

First, bring a blanket and/or chairs. Plan to stay for the day. Everyone is friendly and the event has a laid back carnival atmosphere. No dogs, please. Lots of people very close together and lots of little people running around.

Second, there will be lines. We saw long wait times for the BBQ place, the wood fired pizza with the coolest truck and the Vietnamese truck. Tag team the food runs. Have someone stay at the blanket while others stand in line. 

The weather was perfect, cool with a slight breeze. A magnificent view of the bridge and hosted on the famous Presidio. Did you know you can rent some of the renovated base housing? If I had the money, I would be all over that. 

Oh! There is a free shuttle called the PresidiGo Shuttle. They pick up from downtown and bring you to right across the street from the event.
author: Snow M.

description:
Came here for a family friend's birthday and I had a great time! Plenty of foodtrucks and tents to satisfy your cravings. 

The Paella is definitely a must try,and it's $10 but has meat and shrimps that just mixed so well! 

A tip I suggest is to come early. I ended up arriving before 12 noon,so there was still nearby parking which was easy to find. $1.25 per hour, or $7 all day which isn't bad at all. I do recommend to plan ahead and make sure you bring sun block and a small half tent,and blankets that absorb the wet grass if you plan to stay all day.
author: Samantha M.

description:
I've been to Off the Grid at the Presidio on Thursdays and Sundays.  OtG on Thursdays is for dinner, and there are bungalows that are first come, first serve.  If you're lucky to snag one, you get offered drink service.  OtG on Sundays doesn't have the bungalows, but there are a lot more food carts available.

It's a nice place to enjoy the view of the bridge and eat good food among friends.  Be sure to check out the website to see what trucks and carts are available.
author: Vira P.

description:
Off the grid is a gathering of food trucks and stalls every Sunday at the Presidio from 11-4. Alcohol is available, but everyone was courteous (and if you choose to drink, be considerate of the families around!).

The vibe's like a very large backyard barbecue. Lots of kids, lots of dogs, a giant stereo playing top 40 and, of course, lots of food. Of course, it's seasoned with San Francisco: there's an outdoor yoga class from 11-12 (with a very friendly instructor) and I was approached by 3 (super sweet!) guys passing out fliers for their startups. And, like anywhere else in SF, parking sucks. Be prepared to muni or walk about a mile for any street parking.

Food is good though! I wasn't impressed by the stalls on the right (which I think are mostly cash only), but I liked the selection of food trucks on the left. I think they change every week, but prices ranged from $9-12 (not bad for SF) and the trucks all took card. Great view of the bay! I can see a fun afternoon grabbing lunch before or after biking across the Golden Gate.
author: Varsha S.

description:
One of my most favorite things to do on a sunny Sunday in SF.  Great place to chill with a significant other, dog, family, and/or friends.  This spot is especially family friendly in comparison to the one offered in Fort Mason on Fridays (and much larger with more food options as well).  We love to bring our picnic table, chairs, blanket, and a bottle of bubbly with us, and then grab some grub from the food trucks and hang out for the afternoon.  So chill, so fun.

The only unfortunate thing is it's become increasingly more popular - this year has been the busiest I've seen it.  Just come prepared to have to either get there early or circle the lot stalking people to try to find a parking spot.
author: Rachael S.

description:
When do you ever just get to hang out at the Presidio right in front of the Walt Disney Museum? Well, I don't - I don't know about you! My cousin hosted her birthday celebration here this past Sunday (9/13/15) and it was a lot of fun. It's the most casual meet up for a birthday anyone could have, and everyone's essentially in charge of whatever they wanna bring/order/eat, etc.

At this specific on off the grid, I shared all of the items I ordered.
*I started with Nopalito - and ordered the totopos con chile y picadillo (house made tortilla chips, ground pork, potato, salsa, de arbol, cojita cheese, onion, cilantro and crema ($9) and totally shareable with at least 2-3 other people. This was pretty good! It seemed as if they sprinkled cheddar cheese on the chips, it kind of resembled doritos. 

*To wash it all down we went to Cholita Linda and had their agua frescas. The lady at the cashier was super nice and offered to do a mix of the two flavors they have. So she did half mango-passion fruit and half strawberry-lime --- so refreshing! It was a tad too sweet for me so I ended up adding about a fourth of extra water when I had the space ($3.50)

*For dessert we hit up the creme brulee cart - they had the usual vanilla bean, dark chocolate, salted caramel and the chef's special which was bourbon butterscotch and nutella strawberry ($5/each) as well as other specialty flavors and bits and drizzles as additions (+$1). I had the vanilla bean and this was delicious - as expected! My mom had the salted caramel, it was way too rich, we ended up giving it to someone else in our party to enjoy. My friend got the nutella strawberry and she was basically having mouthgasms from first bite to her last - I think it was pretty good too, but I enjoyed the simplicity of the vanilla bean. 

Minus one star because I think they could've had more options, but other than that, a very enjoyable experience on one of the last Sundays of Summer.

Tips:
-Bring cash if possible. Although most vendors do accept card, it's easier and faster to pay with cash
-Bring your pooch! Dogs are definitely welcomed and allowed
-Bring a blanket to sit on and a tent if possible. 
-Take public transportation or carpool - parking in the lot is $7 all day
author: Kathleene E.

description:
I love OTG ever since they started, they're hugely popular now, and their team comes up with awesome ideas on where to go.  We left AT&T park during a day game and headed to the Presidio.  It was first come, first serve, so we grabbed a cabana and situated ourselves.   A vast array of food trucks at this site with breathtaking views all around.  It was Twilight Thursday with a menu of libations.  Simple steps to order if you're in a cabana, simply text your drink order and flag # of the cabana, and a confirmation will be received.  Just sit back and relax, and your drinks will arrive shortly.  

I ordered all the baos from Chairman Bao, pulled pork sandwiches from The Boneyard, angus beef sliders, and a meat pie from The Creme Brulee Cart.  We chillaxed the rest of the evening with bottles of Coca-Cola, and listened to live music.  Family-friendly, lots of people enjoying their picnics on the lawn, and happy pets trying to snatch your food.  For the Yelper complaining about people sitting too close, get there early and seize your territory, what do you expect when you go to a public venue...people?  Don't be anti-social, and "NO" OTG is not going to enforce people sitting next to each other enjoying the same view.  The whole experience is about people gathering together as people; otherwise, stay home!  SF is home to the hippies, it's all about love, happiness, and peace - nobody is rude here, sounds like you are.
author: Christine R.

description:
Pay for parking, $1.20/hr, or get a ticket. Paying for parking on Sunday sucks! 

This is my favorite Off the Grid spot. Unlike their visits to parts of the bay, At the Presidio provides you a huge grass field for you to picnic, not to mention the wonderful view facing the bay and The Rock. 

Bring a jacket or sweater as it gets pretty chili even during some of the hottest days because of the wind. 

Vendors surround both sides of the field. To the west side are your food trucks. The east side are the farmers' market and more restaurant based food vendors. 

There were a few farmers' market vendors selling local honey and strawberries on the day that I went but not much. 

The vendors often change so I guess you need to go to OffTheGridSF.com to check what's out during that Sunday. 

I love restaurant vendors as they provide, in my opinion, already established quality to the table. I forgot the name of the vendor but I bought some fried chicken at a discounted price right before they were closing and it was pretty good even though it wasn't fresh off the fryer.

Smack dab in the middle of the field are your alcohol stands for beers, wine and mimosas.

A great place to bring a group of friends to enjoy the a picnic out in the sun on a huge field with lots of choices from local food trucks and vendors.
author: Stan L.

description:
After a great weekend at the Inn at the Presidio, we were in the midst of checking out of our hotel and noticed a large crowd gathering in the grass fields. Overlooking the bay and the Golden Gate Bridge, was this amazing out door food gathering called Off the Grid!

There were so many different types of food and drink options that caters to everyone! You want BBQ? It was there! Pizza, Asian fusion, Mexican? It was there! Fresh juice, adult beverages, coffee? It was there! The only trouble is there was so many options that what do you choose? My suggestion is to go hungry, spend the entire 5 hours there, and share share share! This might be the only way to try everything.

There's plenty of parking on the Presidio grounds just make sure you pay the fee otherwise a ticket will be coming. The only main drawback was that there's absolutely no shade. Be prepared and bring some sort of sun shade, similar to what you would bring to the beach.

One of the great aspects to SF and the bay area is the food! Off the Grid is a great way to try many local food vendors without having to go all over the city. Enjoy the food, the views of the bay, and the excellent people watching :)
author: Stan W.

description: Perfect way to spend a nice Sunday afternoon. Bring a blanket and sunscreen then roam around to consider your different food options. When we went, I think there were at least 20 different food vendors. I really enjoyed the skewers truck and the grilled cheese stand! We got there just after noon and there was plenty of sitting space on the grass.
author: Gloria N.

description:
When the weather is nice, it's the perfect place to grab some friends, bring a picnic blanket and just hang out. There's a HUGE grass area where you can chill and hang out in the sun and there's a decent amount of food trucks and food vendors. The is also a great view of the water as well if you go to one end of the park.

Bonus: they sell drinks as well (but you can always bring your own).

Overall, it's a perfect place to have a lazy weekend and just hang out.
author: Sophia Y.

description: Such a fun day. If you have never been to Off the Grid, you are missing out! Food, food, food and drink EVERYWHERE. The DJ was playing great music. There was even a modified CTrain on a flat bed that had been turned into a pizza eatery equipped with a pizza oven! I'm definitely trying it next time. Lots of variety. You can most definitely find something for everyone. Bring your blanket and sun block.  But hurry up because it stops November 1st.
author: Debbie K.

description: My new fav discovery in SF. I love Off The Grid Presidio! Bomb cocktails + gourmet food trucks + beautiful bay view = best thing ever. This is such a fun thing to do with your friends or family. Make sure to bring your chairs and blankets! Then you can find a spot in the grass and sit in the sun :)
author: Nicole W.

description:
I really enjoy heading into off the grid in the presidio on Sunday's. We (my wife and nearly 2 year old daughter) have been a few times and are slowly becoming seasoned into what to do and bring.

The basics:
- Layers - the weather can literally be different from the presidio and the next neighborhood across. We live very close and one time I went without my wife. I came back drenched, cold and miserable. My wife didn't even see a cloud.
- Sunscreen - if the weather is good it is easy to sit, drink, eat and relax for a little too long in the sun.
- Time - some of the food trucks (like the pizza one) can have massive lines. Make sure to come that little bit before you are hungry. Although there are still places where you can get a meal straight away.
- Picnic blanket - there is no seating here, it is a giant chunk of grass. The grass is nice and soft, but it is nicer if you are sitting on something else.

Advanced:
- Drinks - even though getting a Bloody Mary from the dude pushing around the cart is nice, paying $18 isn't. Grab some wine, beer or whatever from home. You can always grab something to try when you are there but it isn't super necessary.
- Wind/sun shelter - what is it with parks without trees/shelter in this city? The wind up here can be pretty strong, plus you are sitting exposed for a long time while picnicking.
- Sports equipment - there is free rentable stuff at a stall near the entrance. You just have to leave your ID. Things go quickly so make sure to check out what is available when you arrive.
author: Tristan L.

description:
When you can spend an afternoon hanging out with friends, drinking beer and eating great food -- all without having to do any food prep or setup yourself -- why would you spend a Sunday any other way?

We had a great group picnic at OTG and got lucky with beautiful weather. It was surprisingly easy for us to find our friends (and a great spot) in the crowd, and it turns out that the OTG team will even rent you comfy lawn chairs and blankets (super useful if you're an out-of-towner.) (PRO TIP: Call ahead to reserve your chairs/blankets, and they'll set it all up for you! $5 per chair or blanket, so for $60 you get a roomy outdoor living circle for a dozen friends + kids in the middle!)

The food options were great: fried chicken, waffles, coffee, ice cream, delicious pizza -- and yes, there is healthy stuff too, if you have the self-restraint to choose it when you're standing next to the fried chicken place.

A totally delightful way to spend a Sunday!
author: Alexandra S.

description: Great sunday funday activity! Depending on the unpredictable SF weather of course. All in all, it's awesome to have good food, good music, good views and last but not least all you need to bring with you is good company! Enjoyed presidio picnic and would recommend to bring your own picnic suppies ie: mats, chairs, tables and/or open tent (considering SF windy/cloudy days).
author: Crisgel B.

description:
Such a fun time. I've gone twice now, once on a weekend afternoon and once on a Thursday evening. There's some seriously great food trucks here including The Lobsta Truck and An's Noodles (always a favorite). 

I would recommend the daytime weekend version because its much warmer than the Thursday evening (we had particularly bad luck since it was foggy that day). 

Food is kind of expensive, (Lobster truck more so-- $20 for a lobster roll with extra meat, (that's what she said) and $14 for just a regular lobster roll, burgers from Bacon are ~$9-12). They have a booze truck in the evenings and in the daytime weekend versions they have a booze truck AND a slightly pretentious slow drip, personalized, Peets style coffee station too.

Beautiful views of the bay and the bridge!
author: Lai-Nin W.

description: Lovely atmosphere. Beautiful surroundings. A lot of food to choose from. The peruvian food truck is especially good.
author: Carol K.

description:
I was finally able to attend this event! Can't go wrong with being able to try different food trucks and relaxing on the grass on a nice day! It's not like the usual OTG at Fort Mason. This event has less food trucks. But still a good amount. The lawn they host it next to is pretty big! And parking isn't a big problem since theres parking lots all around the area. I would highly recommend attending one of these picnics while it's still going on! 

When I went.. I tried 4 different spots. grilled cheese guy, wing wing, go streatery and fins on the hoof! At the Grilled Cheese guy I ordered the Not your average grilled cheese, it was good. They add a little spice to it which makes it good. At wing wing, we ordered the fried chicken...... amazingly good!!!!! It would have to be my favorite out of all the spots I tried. I highly recommend trying the fried chicken there. At go steatery... I ordered the oxtail over grits and the donuts. The oxtail was delicious! They weren't joking about it being "fall off the bone" and the donuts were ok. Lastly, I had the soft shell crAb po boy at fins on the hoof. It was delicious!! I would definitely order it again.
