Overall it was a great experience! Come prepared! Being picnic blankets.. Chairs.. Etc! Anything that will help you enjoy and be comfortable!
author: Jadelann J.

description:
This was a really great place to spend our Sunday afternoon during the 4th of July weekend. It was nice and sunny until later in the afternoon, and there's a huge grassy, overall flat open space for people to sit and have a nice relaxing picnic.

There was a decent range of food trucks and different types of food, including desserts, Asian food, fried chicken, paella, and Vietnamese food. However, unsurprisingly most of these seemed slightly overpriced and the more popular trucks weren't there. I ended up ordering from the Asian Skewers food truck and I was very satisfied with the food! I got the skewer combo, which comes with 1 chicken skewer, 1 marinated beef, and grilled veggies. The beef was pretty undercooked so it looked like medium rare steak, but I ate all of it and didn't feel any discomfort. The chicken and beef were both super tender, juicy, and well-flavored. 

Also, dogs! They were everywhere at the picnic and I loved that. Overall a laid-back, fun way to spend a lazy Sunday afternoon and get some noms in!
author: Kailin H.

description:
I missed out on the inaugural run of Off The Grid Picnic at the Presidio so I can't really tell what's changed.  From what I've read, they've added a farmers' market and changed up some of the food vendors.

It's definitely a departure from all the other OTGs since there are less trucks and more restaurant based vendors, not to mention the farmers' market.  They rotate some of the vendors like the other OTGs and also in some cases they seem to be more pricier than at the other OTGs.

Here are some of the usual vendors:
Fins on the Hoof
The Creme Brulee Cart 
The Whole Beast
Kasa Indian Eatery
Cholita Linda
El Porteno,
Namu Gaji
Wing Wings
Del Popolo
Humphry Slocombe
Rosamunde Sausage
Tataki

I was definitely was happy to see Del Popolo there as they're one of my favorite pizzas. Tataki had a nice deal where you can select 2 items from their menu for $8.  And The Whole Beast always has some epic sandwich that's different every week.  They had a smoked turkey sandwich one time that was so good!!

And it's just nice to be able to enjoy your food out on the grass with a view of the bay, especially when the weather is good.  This is their 2nd year doing this and I hope they bring this back again next year!!
author: Rodney H.

description:
This is a cool idea and a great way to spend a Sunday afternoon. The only drawbacks are the difficulty in finding parking and the huge lines at every food vendor.

Once past that, there is ample space to claim for yourself and the variety of food is outstanding. After getting your fill, head over to the Disney Museum!
author: Gene D.

description:
While I LOVE Presidio Picnic and I think it's the best OTG out there, I think they really need to make some organizational improvements. 

Judging by the Facebook event and other promotions they did ahead of the first event of the season this past Sunday, I was shocked to see how unprepared they were for the amount of people who attended. Now I know lines and crowds are a given, but literally everything had almost a 45 minute wait. Since the main attraction is the food, I didn't mind the wait there as much, but these lines also carried over to the bathrooms. They had a little trailer with a total of 2 men's single stall bathrooms, 1 women's single stall, and a women's 3 stall. There was also a handicap private restroom, however, that one was quickly put out of commission. That means there were a total of 5 bathrooms for a crowd which probably reached at least 1,000 people, if not more. Everyone in line, including myself, nearly had an accident as we waited about 45 minutes to finally get to the front of the line. Not only is that ridiculous, but it is clearly a health and safety concern. I asked around to see if there were any other bathroom stations, and was told that these were the only ones. Very poor planning in my opinion. 

I'm not sure what sort of restrictions they put on this space, but I really hope they do something throughout the Presidio Picnic season to resolve these issues. If there's a way to spread things out over the entire lawn so the crowds do not all congregate in one tiny area, or at the very least if they can arrange for more restrooms, that would be a great start.
author: Jaymie S.

description:
I had never imagined anything like what I saw in "Off the Grid" at the Presidio. I've seen Off the Grid food trucks quite a few times on Lawrence Expressway in Sunnyvale, but never been there. So, when my friends recommended going to the one in Presidio, I had just imagined a few food trucks in a street corner.

But it turned out to be like night and day. It was on a HUGE lawn in front of the Walt Disney Museum and there were aplenty of food trucks and ice-cream trucks.

After walking around all the food trucks, we got Mediterranean shawarmas. The portions are huge and they were good.

You can bring your chairs or tents or even bring your own food and sit on the lawn, while enjoying the beautiful SF weather and watching the bay at a distance.

Totally unique experience. I'd definitely come here again when I visit the city another time.
author: Anu M.

description:
I like the vibe of this Off the Grid a lot. It's in such a great place and there were a ton of people sitting and enjoying the event. There were a lot more options for food trucks compared to other Off the Grids that I've seen around the Bay Area. There was also a good variety of food trucks- there were Asian, Mediterranean, Indian, Mexican, and American food trucks. 

The food was decent, but pretty pricey. We paid around $7 for a skewer and fries, which were both relatively small servings. 

I would recommend going to this Off the Grid, but just be prepared to spend a lot on small portions.
author: Arianna B.

description: Came here for a friend's 32nd birthday party on Sunday. I live in the East Bay and got there very easily (and very cheaply!) via Bart and the Presidigo Shuttle (free, every half hour from Market and Drumm - right next to Embarcadero Bart). You have to pay for parking. There were lots of people, but it felt a lot calmer and more relaxed than spending the afternoon at Dolores. Wide range of people - good for young adults, families with kids, etc. I greatly enjoyed the garlic noodles from Little Green Cycle and gelato from Luciano's.
author: Shoshana G.

description:
The kick off of Off the Grid in the Presidio!!!!! It was a beautiful Sunday afternoon. Tents were lined up along the side and food trucks were right across. The alcoholic beverages were served smack in the middle. Many people were laying on the grass so be sure not to step on anyone or any animal!

Not my first rodeo at an Off the Grid event, so I knew the lines were going to be long. Don't let the long lines ruin your experience (4 stars) and bring cash just in case. The vendors at this event was a perfect variation. Just to name a
few they had: The Whole Beast, Cholita Linda, Chotto, and Salumeria (sp?). Come early!!! Parking is a little challenging and some tents will run out of items on their menu. 

The lines will definitely discourage you from experiencing many of the vendors; hence, I highly recommend to come with a group and fan out! Haha. This way you can get several things at once and just share. 

Definitely would love to go to some of the vendors actual restaurants when I get a chance. From what I had, the food was amazing.
author: Jenna T.

description:
By far one of my favorite things about San Francisco. It's just another example of why my heart belongs to San Francisco. 
Every time I come and visit I make sure to try and  experience the city's culinary scene as much as possible since the city is known for such a diverse food culture. 
The picnic in the presidio allowed me to try a ton of different foods, on a beautiful summer day in the park overlooking the Golden Gate Bridge! 

I was stoked to see Nopalito there. I had just watched their diners drive in and dives episode and my mouth was seriously watering as I was watching the episode on TV! We tried the totopos con Chile which are Tortilla chips, salsa de arbol, cotija cheese, crema and lime. Seriously to die for and very spicy! Reason alone to come back to the city! 

The Creme brûlée cart which had a wide assortment of seriously decadent creme brûlée. We tried 5 different flavors and they were all to die for! The unbirthday cake and the god father were the two winners! The staff working were funny and extremely
helpful!

Fine and Rare: I tried their oyster po boy which was way to much bread and not enough oysters! But the flavor was amazing and the oysters were fried to perfection. You could see the quality of their ingredients. But for $14.00, my sandwich which was pretty small I don't think I will be rushing back here!

Picnic bar and liberations had a super cute mimosa kit which come with a bottle of champs, two mixers (oj and a strawberry lemonade) in a bucket! Their Mr Pickles Bloody Mary was yummy and full of flavor and came with amazing pickles garnishes! They even offer blanket side service! 

Most venders were equipped to take credit
Cards and lines moved pretty quickly. I recommend arriving a little early if your brave enough to drive your own car as parking can be a pain! 

Yet another thing that San Fran does right! When will Los Angeles learn?!
author: Roxy H.

description: This review is for Presidio's Off the Grid Twilight edition on Thursdays.  My kids and I went to our first Off the Grid picnic and got there around 7:30pm, there were lots of Food Trucks to choose from but not as much as I thought, maybe 8 total.  We weren't able to sit at a campfire or have a cabana since we arrived kind of late, I guess you have to get there early for that, they start at 4pm-9pm.  The band that played was good.  The food was good, I had the Shrimp Po Boy and my kids had burger sliders, veggie burger and fries.  Not a lot of options for the vegans like StreatFood Park has.  Veggie burger was good, my daughter said though.  The day we went was a nice light evening since the Warriors were playing their Finals.  Nice place for kids to run around and play catch, listen to music, eat some grub, drink beer and wine, and enjoy the beautiful view of the Bay.
author: Rosie M.

description:
A wonderful Sunday gathering.  Come with blankets, jackets, and all else necessary to enjoy your time while here.  A great place to be with loved ones for a relaxed afternoon/evening following a day of adventure in SF or Marin.  

Tip: bike in if able, parking can get tricky.  We usually park on the street in the surrounding area and bike in.  If you are feeling a bit more playful, park closer to Golden Gate Park and bike from there after exploring the park.
author: Gab R.

description:
I had been meaning to check out OTG Twilight at the Presidio since first hearing about it in April, and finally made it out on a windy Thursday in May.

Arriving at 4:50pm, the field was only sparsely filled. If you wanted to nab a cabana or a fire pit, now until maybe 5:15pm would be a good time to do it, as only a few were claimed with people's belongings. No one actually sat in the cabanas or fired up their pits until maybe 5:30 or 6:00. 

I was disappointed to see that there were only 8-10 food trucks present; not the entire lineup that was presented online. Of the few, I decided to get Koja (has never failed me), Kokio (who says no to Korean fried chicken?), and Pagan Fired Pizza (friend is obsessed with analyzing peoples' pizzas). OTG is a great place to grab tried-and-true goodies and check out some new ones too. 

The fire pits and the cabanas are a nice touch to the event, but I did not stick around to enjoy either, as it was way too windy. This event is pet friendly, as evidenced by the 5-6 dogs I encountered on the field there. Live music started at around 6:00pm.

Overall, the concept is great, but the food truck lineup was paltry and it was just way too windy that day to enjoy the space and the food. May consider revisiting if I have a large group of friends that wants to check it out and the weather decides to warm up.
author: Shirley V.

description:
Hidden gem! So basically Off The Grid hosts food picnic events here every Sunday through Fall from 11am-4pm for free(Just pay for your food if you didn't bring any, and for parking). This place is never too crowded (hardly tourists). 


Words cannot describe how beautiful and awesome the vibes are at this place on Sunday's especially when it's sunny outside. The grass is so green and there's an awesome view of the water, and the sail boats are out! When you're in SF, and it's a beautiful Sunday, this is the PERFECT place to go with a group of friends, family, loved ones,dogs, kids, etc. to have some mimosas or a couple beers, eat away, lay out, take a nap and just chill. It's very family and dog friendly.


Its  literally a huge grass field with a bunch of food and alcohol vendors and a bunch of people just vibing on a Sunday. 

BYOB! Meaning bring your own blankets to sit on and you can also bring your own brew :) the alcohol there is pretty expensive, but the $10 tequila drink got me on a good one lol. Make sure to bring a jacket because the wind can pick up . 

ALSO, the food is not like food truck portions, they're actually pretty decent sized! They offer healthy to not so healthy foods.

Did I also mention that there's live music too.
author: Hayle C.

description:
Can't think of a better way to spend a beautiful sunny day in San Francisco!

I met up with some friends here on a gorgeous Sunday afternoon. The view of the bay was amazing. We brought our picnic blanket and set up near the DJ. I love that there is plenty of parking, which is hard to come by in the city. There is plenty of space for everyone to spread out. It is family friendly and dog friendly. 

There are plenty of food truck options and the best part is that there is a bar! We brought some of our own drinks but I also enjoyed the Bloody Mary and Moscow Mule from the bar.

In terms of food, you can't go wrong with the fried chicken from Wing Wing's! So good! Watch out for that hot sauce though.

If you are looking for a low-key way to spend an afternoon in the city then I would highly recommend OTG Presidio Picnic!
author: Patricia L.

description:
I am only reserving a star because of my own personal bias, this is a family friendly affair.  To some extent I LOVE that about the location because it is over the sprawling Presidio lawn, food trucks galore, and cocktails in the sun.  What more could one possibly need?  Bring your sun hat, a blanket, and hang out as the day allows.  

My issue, the rampant crazy children running around like banshees and their parents who do nothing about it.  This has nothing to do with the event itself, the location, or even vendors.  Just be aware, to be in the mood for wild children all around you.  Other than the restless natives, it is a perfect way to spend an afternoon in the sun.

The food truck options are expansive and to be honest I'm not sure if it changes week to week, so I know when I went everything was covered from various Mexican options, Coffee, BBQ, breakfast, Asian flair, and even GF bakery.  

I love the culture of the event more than any one specific option available.  Bring your blanket, chair or whatever you want to relax in the sun, a book, frisbee, cards, whatever and chill.  Soak up the sun, grab a bite, and enjoy the incredible SF bay view.  It's a good way to remember why we are so lucky here in the North Bay.
author: Mandy L.

description:
Love it!  We thought we'd give it a try on Mother's day and we'll definitely be coming back again.  There's tons of great food, spectacular views, and general relaxation.  An awesome time all around.

Notes:
- The lawn gets crowded right in the middle but there's plenty of space for everyone.  I didn't notice a single person being an asshole which was refreshing.  Nice folks, respectful of eachother,etc.

-  Parking can be a challenge.  If you go in one of the paid lots, it's $7 for the whole day.  I noticed many people cabbing/ubering in as the day went on.  If you live in the city, this is probably a great way to go

- Bring a picnic blanket and chairs so you can relax on the lawn.  It can be a bit of a walk to the food trucks and we saw several people with trays to carry their food.  Not a bad idea.

- Very family friendly, we saw kids from toddler age all the way up to teenagers.

- Dog friendly but your dog has to be on a leash.  All the dog owners seemed to be very responsible with their pets (including us) so that was nice to see

-  We froze our asses off most of the day so it's best to be prepared for all kinds of weather.  You're right on the bay

-  There are two bars but they are very expensive for the amount of hooch you get so plan accordingly.  $10 for a small glass of wine, $5 for beers, and $10 for mixed drinks...not a bargain

-  Our group tried a bunch of different food trucks and it seriously adds up money wise so if you have the space, it's good to pack some essentials like water and snacks for the kids to keep the cost down

-  The crowd is a very good mix of people.  Tons of families, tons of hipsters, and all ethnicities and ages so nobody should worry about feeling out of place.  

- I don't think it would be ideal for disabled people unless they have others who can carry the food, stand in line, etc.  Could be rough for someone to manage if they were in a wheelchair or needed to use a cane.
author: Jonathan A.

description:
The ultimate Off The Grid event! From brick and mortar restaurants to food trucks you'll find many options to satisfy any food cravings you may have. The cuisine ranges from American, Japanese, Indian. Spanish, Mexican and more! There are designated alcoholic beverage stations too. The event is well organized. Folks simply need to fall in line after they figured out their food preferences. The grilled cheese vendor had the longest line! Restrooms are clean and not too far from the grounds. There are lots of garbage cans around the perimeter to make it really easy for event attendees to keep the lawn clean and tidy.

The event takes place in front of the Walt Disney Museum. There is a lawn so bring a blanket or a mini tent. There are games for rent too. 

Getting there: most folks drive but we like to walk. If you live in SF and love to walk and Uber or Lyft.  I highly recommend it so as not to worry about traffic. The Golden Gate Bridge, Crissy Field and the Presidio trails are close by if you want to add a little hike before or after brunch
author: Jessica V.

description: I went to the Off-the-Grid Food Truck party and it made for an incredible weekend. You get the best view of the ocean and it such a nice place to relax with friends under the sun. I've been hanging out there on sunny weeks and it is so peaceful.
author: Izzy N.

description:
This is the quintessential Sunday afternoon in San Francisco.  The views are spectacular, with iconic Presidio architecture, the Golden Gate Bridge and Alcatraz, in a rare expanse of open, green space.  

The food options are incredible, with a wide variety of both artisan and comfort foods.  Add the bar, music, and games, and it's a perfect picnic.  You can rent blankets and tents, and buy mimosa and bloody mary kits.  

Some tips:
Sunscreen - you'll need it. they have it at the information booth if you forget.
Cash - wifi problems mean slow credit card processing.  there is an ATM
Parking - come early, or ride your bike
Kids - come early, it turns more adult as the afternoon progresses
Dogs - the more the better

This would definitely make my top 10 list of things to do in SF.
author: kimberley t.

description:
This is such a fun and relaxing outing, especially on a sunny Sunday afternoon.  I love the open grass area with the view of the bay. There is no shortage of food with all the food trucks and food boothes lined up around the grass area.  There is a nice bar in the center serving beer, wine and various cocktails. And to top it off, there is a DJ playing music.  

If you are on a tight budget, this is something you should add to your list. You can always bring your own picnic and drinks. I see families there, dogs, big groups of friends gathering, people who find a cozy spot alone to read their books. It's a great place for everybody!  

Parking is usually pretty easy but make sure to pay the meter!
author: Mel D.

description: I really enjoyed this off the grid event!  The amount of vendors, the grassy area, the DJ playing music and the cool breeze of the coastal area really made this a relaxing event.  Everyone was enjoying themselves out here: couples, friends and family all just having a relaxing and fun time.  If you are looking for an event to hang out, enjoy some awesome food and relax...  THIS IS THE PLACE TO BE!  Just make sure you bring some sunblock... you have been warned :)
author: Jose C.

description:
Great off the grid concept because it's a picnic in SF!  Great way to spend a day in the city on a Sunday.  Bring a blanket and relax with the family, your dog, or your friends. But, the food selection wasn't that great in my opinion. 

- Del Popolo was the longest line, but it was ok, (3/5 stars) Margarita $11 and Sausage $14.  I don't think it was really worth the wait...
- GO STREATERY was the best for the oxtail and grits! (4/5 stars) the oxtail was fall-off-the-bone meat, but the grits had too much of a lemon taste, I could only handle a bit of it

There were also rosamunde sausages (get their rattlesnake sausages!), tataki, namu gaji (korean which i heard wasn't that great), wing wings ($14 for 4 pieces....wtf?!), coffee, ice cream, and of course creme brulee cart.  

OVERALL: nice to spend your lunch on a weekend, but I'd only come back if they had a better selection!
author: Raquel Y.

description:
Awesome location when it's sunny out! There's plenty of space to sprawl out or play some frisbee on the lawn. It's a gathering of people (and dogs) of all ages! 

They have both food trucks as well as booths where food vendors without trucks can also sell their goods. Some of the highlights were Tout Patisserie, Wing Wings, The Whole Beast, The Grilled Cheez Guy, and the Crème Brûlée cart. There's also a wine and beer bar, which make this more of an "adult" picnic ;) 

If you're going to be there for a few hours, it could be a good idea to bring some shade. Some groups brought these half dome tents that were a good shield against the sun (and wind). 

As you walk closer to the water, you can get a pretty good view of the Golden Gate Bridge. Great place to chill on a lazy Sunday afternoon.
author: Audrey L.

description:
Pros: Super fun. Loads of space even when it's crowded. A million food options. Kid, dog and everything else friendly. 

Down sides: Lines are long. Drinks are pricy. Weather in the presidio is weather in the presidio.  

Hints: BYO everything - blanket, sun shade / sunscreen, seating, alcohol. Parking isn't super easy, so plan to walk a little bit or get there early.
author: who k.

description:
Pretty location with great views of the Bay. However since it's so deep in the Presidio you are basically forced to drive here or catch an uber. Such is the way of San Francisco.

I was a bit disappointed with the vendors here because the food was quite expensive and there weren't that many dessert food trucks. Also the one coffee shop didn't have decaf!
author: Danielle C.

description: Off the Grid at the Presidio is always a good time. Great food, reasonable prices, and a picturesque backdrop.
author: Alexandra F.

description:
One of the reasons why I love the Bay Area -- it's so easy to head out on a whim to the marina on a sunny day in October and just hang out with a few friends over good food and wine.  Events like this OTG are the perfect complement!  No need to stress about marinating your veggies, filling the ice chest or packing the picnic basket -- just bring your blanket and let the food trucks do the work. Done!

My fave food trucks: Rosamunde Sausage Grill, Namu Gaji, Cholita Linda and the Creme Brulee Cart. Add to that, there's a good DJ to provide the music, and there's a cabana serving up cocktails and wine.  If you need to sneak in some shopping, there is also a small farmer's market.  If you've got kids, the Walt Disney museum is a few steps away.  But really, the best part is just hanging out and meeting new people who feel just as lucky to live in such a gorgeous city where something like this OTG thrives.  

Tip: It only runs on Sundays from April to October, so enjoy it while it lasts!
author: Dawne L.

description: I love OTG and whenever I am in SF I must, must go to an OTG somewhere. This location is awesome!!!  Gorgeous views, music, lots of great food, (there are less trucks but still lots of options), and bars!!! woohoo!!  While you are on line for food they wheel around a wagon and will bring you drinks while you wait. Brilliant! Whats better than that???? Bring a blanket, bring your kids, your pets, a frisbee, some games. Its fun for all!!!! Stay the day and relax and enjoy
author: Karen R.

description:
There are so many things that I can say proudly about San Francisco and I cannot stress how fantastic Off the Grid is to newbies or tourists.  This is something not alot of outta towners know, nothing printed in any tourist catalogs, and certainly not a word of this spoken on those ridiculous double decker buss'.  Simply put, if you really wanna see the city beyond it's commercialism, this is the way to go!  

The grass area is huge for hundreds of people with pets and families to lay their blankets on the grass, kick off their shoes, put some sunglasses on, and take down a cold one.  You can see people playing little games, tossing Frisbee for their dogs, or taking a nap.   

Venders are located along the side of the grass area.  They have small booths set up next to one another for easy viewing and trucks along the opposite side with their colorful trucks.  A few stands throughout the picnic area that either sell beer, mixed drinks, or game rentals.  

The place is kept clean since there's constant trash patrol going around emptying bins and picking up debris.  Parking isn't free so prepare to toss a few bucks in the meters (everyday parking permits required).  

Make sure to bring come cash.  But if you forgot, there are a few ATM machines scattered all throughout.
author: Lea M.

description:
UMMMM, yes.  All things yes.  Sunday Brunch on the lawn with champagne, a blanket, and food trucks?  YES. 

I hate being referred to one of those people, but I enjoy everything about Sunday picnics at the presidio.  Food trucks galore, plenty of booze, and people watching.   Sure, you can expect the same food stands, but the trucks rotate. 

####Parking: hard to find FREE.  If you don't mind paying 4-5 bucks for the afternoon, there's plenty of options. The parking meters accept credit cards, so don't fret.

####Weather: It's SF. Karl the Fog will inevitable make an appearance or not. Dress accordingly in layers. I have been when it's hot and freezing.  

#####Requirements: Blanket, extra food and or snacks-depending on how much you want to spend-libations, fold up chairs, pillows, baby wipes, and napkins. 

#####Food: El Potrero, Nopalito, and the Whole Beast are my personal favorite. I also like the Grilled cheese guys, and the Sugarfoot Grits.  There's something good for all.  

####Drinks: PASS and bring your own.  What a rip off for a bloody mary.  Just say no. 

Props for the DJ spinning beats, and Sports Basement for making an appearance.
author: Flor D.

description:
Was spending my Sunday morning exploring some of the areas in eastern san Francisco when my stomach began to rumble.  My husband I did some research and saw this place.  We were familiar with off the grid but had not been to one yet.  Headed over and got there around noon.  Parking was easy!  The market started at 11 and went to 4 I think the earlier you get there the better.  We had no issues with parking at all.

Walking over to the market it looked sooo big, I was getting more and more exciting.  Live music and a great view add to the ambiance!  I had no idea there would be alcohol options!  That was an exciting surprise!  They had a bubble bar and a regular bar tent.  I enjoyed a delicious sangria at the bubble bar and my husband got a beer.

From there we did a round..there were a ton of vendors.  So many to choose from.  Tons of variety.  The trucks change every week so every time you go it will be different.  I cant wait to go back!
author: Kate F.

description:
Other Off the Grid chains have definitely amazed me, but none of them has been as spectacular as this one. This particular Off The Grid is one that I would definitely recommend people to visit because it's not like the other chains at all. First off, the view is absolutely beautiful and relaxing. You'll find families or friends scattered all over the Presidio lawn with their tents, picnic blankets, dogs (yes, this place is dog-friendly!) and more. You can even catch a glimpse of the Golden Gate Bridge! Your food trucks are lined up in an organized fashion along the sidewalk, making it easy to navigate through and find your desired entree.

From seeing signs to looking up the information on their website, Off The Grid at the Presidio is open EVERY Sunday from 11AM - 4PM. We went here for one of my friend's birthdays and it is definitely a nice place to kick back on a sunny day. There is so much space for any party to sit down, but I would suggest bringing a ton of picnic blankets or towels! This OTG pretty much radiates those laid-back, "kickback" vibes similar to one of those family barbeques you have in your backyard or similar to a picnic at the famous Mission Dolores Park.

I'm not sure if the food vendors switch every Sunday, but Off The Grid always contains enough variety with each visit. This Off The Grid has way more vendors, and thus food entrees, to choose from out of the rest of the chains. From being a previous fan of many Off The Grid places, my food experience was still over-the-top amazing. First, I went to a booth named "Chotto" and ordered Kimchi Fried Rice with Pork Belly and Gyoza. Though the fried rice felt like it was lacking kimchi, it was pretty flavorful rice that kept my stomach happy. The pork belly in the rice dish was excessively fatty, but I mean...it was pretty darn good. The gyoza was very delicious and came with a sweet dipping sauce. I finished all of my food before my friend even received hers, which pretty much gives you a good idea of how food the good is. Lastly, I went to a booth that sold "Three Twins" ice cream and I ordered the Mocha Difference. $3.00 for this cup of ice cream isn't a terrible deal in my opinion, but there was nothing spectacular about this ice cream brand. I would probably suggest ordering a different dessert to make your money more worth it, such as the Creme Brulee Cart.

All in all, I had a great time at Off The Grid in Presidio. I want to warn you that it IS going to be a bit pricey with any vendor that you go to, but the great quality of the food and the fun vibes definitely make it worth your money. My friends and I enjoyed the atmosphere so much that we are debating on coming back next week!
author: Michelle S.

description:
I have a long commute to get home from San Francisco after work every day, so I don't usually stay in the city after work. When I heard about Twilight at the Presidio, I was intrigued. My friend had coincidentally made plans to go as well, so I thought I would check it out. 

TIP: get there at 5pm or earlier to get a tent (up for 4 people) or firering (5+ people), the events gets crowded and these get taken first, obviously.

Why does the Presidio have to be so far away from the main lines of transport (Bart/Caltrain)? It would be so awesome if Bart was closer...wishful thinking. I looked up Muni routes to get from work to the Presidio and it was going to take OVER AN HOUR (from FiDi). WHAT?! I walked to my friend's office near Embarcadero and requested a Sidecar. He got us there in 30. If you're a Presidio resident, you can take the PresidiGO shuttle for free.

I loved the truck line up when I went: Bacon Bacon (my friend got a delicious breakfast burrito), Little Red Riding Truck (I got the Bratwurst with potatoes and sauerkraut, delicious!!), Casey's Pizzaria, Lobsta Truck, and others. We got dessert at Keep Rolling (Chimney Cake, a Hungarian dessert; the cinnamon one is like a churro) and hot spiced apple cider, A MUST! It was gloomy and windy, so the hot drink was perfect. They have other drinks too. 

The most important stuff:
Off The Grid at the Presidio + alcohol - DO IT!
MUST: hot spiced apple cider
Don't drive...parking is a nightmare. Use a ride share service/Muni/PresidiGO
Get there early at 5pm if you want a tent or fire ring
author: Katherine S.

description:
This was so cool! A huge grassy field, bordered by the Walt Disney museum and a view of the bay with a line of food trucks against the sidewalk. 

Fire pits and white alcove tents dot the field and a live band plays music on the grass. On a blustery day, it was pretty perfect sitting here around a blazing fire, drinking hot spiced cider and eating amazing steamed buns from the food truck watching the sun set in the distance.
author: Jonathan Y.

description:
Love this event! 

The food here is setup via food trucks and tents and always changing. The first time I was here last summer, we got this amazing oxtail and grits dish that was amazingggg and this time some Vietnamese grilled pork vermicelli with egg. YUM!

This area seems to be always sunny and there is a huge grassy field that everyone sets up camp with their blankets and umbrellas. The atmosphere is amazing and very family friendly! Lots of people bring their toddlers and dogs here to play in the sun. The parents are happily sipping on wine and chatting with each other and kids are running around chasing bubbles or falling over into the green grass.

What's not to like here! This is the life :')
author: Seliya G.

description:
Second time coming here and loved it, filled with people.

Although food and drinks are expensive, you're paying for the view, the crowd, the music, the inability to find parking on a perfect day. But it is definitely worth it!
author: Da X.

description: Parking is a little difficult depending what time you come and don't forget to pay! It's not free. Bring a blanket and some chairs because the lawn is super nice to hang out on and they even have some games for people to play with. Many vendors and they change weekly but some are set and stone from what I noticed.
author: Alyssa M.

description: Picnic @ the presidio is the best out of all of the grid events. Great food selections, shorter lines, less crowded, and most importantly you can sit anywhere you want.
author: Martinus S.

description:
So today was my first time here, it was great! There was a big grass area where you can put down blankets or chairs to hang out. One side is lined up with food trucks and the other side was lined with tents (food and other things to buy) & of course a couple of bars, but plently of ppl brought their own. There was a gorgeous view of the ocean as well!

I was so hungry I only scouted around the food trucks (sigh, I should've walked around the whole place, there were so many more choices). 

*Fins on Hoof 
Chicken and peas poutine 3.5 stars: I popped my poutine cherry here today (tmi???). I had my mind set on the grass fed lamb burger, but someone walked by with the poutine and I just had to change my mind. So this one is chicken pot pie contents poured over a bed of fries, with a kicker,  cheese curds! It was tasty, but I would've liked a lil more saltiness (maybe some bacon?!!!)

The other locations seem to have a different menu with a whole lotta poutine! I like the idea of poutine and definitely want to try more.
author: Thuy N.

description:
My favorite off the grid spot. Beautiful view of the water and plenty of luscious grass to lay a blanket down on. Come here early if you even want a chance at securing a lantern tent.  Gets chilly being at the top of the mountain so be sure to bring blankets. I even saw people bring in their own tent (very smart).

If you don't get a tent, be sure to move your blanket near a firepit. It will help you stay warm and toasty!

Plenty of good food my favorites being the BBQ truck & the root beer float one. I waited in line for each of them for about 30 minutes.
author: Lauren K.

description:
This is by far the best Off the Grid event. It has most of the same food trucks as the others in SF,  but the setting is extraordinary! There is a beautiful view of boats on the bay.  There are fire pits and cabanas to keep you cozy and warm on chilly evenings.  The whole thing is set on a nice big grassy area with lots of space for kids and adults to play,  dance,  and run around.  

We all had the Bao buns from The Chairman's.  They were delicious as usual.  My favorite is the crispy tofu on the steamed bun.  The pork belly is also quite tasty.  There are cocktails available but I didn't get one this time since I had to work early in the morning. I'll have to come back to try them out.  

The band that was playing was called Wild Couch.  Their music was fun and added nicely to the ambiance.  My 2 year old had a great time dancing!

I'll definitely be going back next week to try some cocktails and different foods trucks.
author: Sarah M.

description:
We've been regulars at Off the Grid in Haight for several years now, but last weekend was the first time we've made it out to this event. We're definitely going to start working this into our weekend routine!
Everything was basically perfect this past Sunday, with a big assist from mother nature who obliged with a "hot" day (scare quotes included b/c it was SF hot, not really hot).
Despite the crowd, there was ample space for lounging on the luxurious Presidio grass. The view is, of course, ridiculous. And, this being OTG, there was tons of great food to choose from. Lines got a little crazy, but that's to be expected at an event this size, and overall they did a pretty good job of moving people through.
Kudos to the drink stand as well. I was expecting nothing but beers, but they were also putting out some pretty solid mixed drinks (including a very yummy bloody mary). The music was a nice touch, and I liked the fact that it wasn't turned up to an obnoxious level (something that occasionally happens at the Haight OTG, depending on who's manning the music tent). 
Don't know if it was related to this event or not, but there was also a little Shakespeare in the park production going on nearby. We stopped in there for a while, but the toddlers we had in tow quickly lost the finer points of Shakespearean dialogue and strenuously suggested we move on.
author: Pat M.

description: Had such a great time! Bring a blanket and layers and you're set! We tried so many different foods and enjoyed just sitting on the grass while listening to the music. The trucks all take credit card which is so convenient.
author: Susan G.

description:
Off the Grid at the Presidio is my favorite location for Off the Grid.  The best parts

-  You get to overlook the Golden Gate Bridge.  So you can cross off seeing the bridge and have a great picnic all in the same day.

-  Cute dogs!  When you're living 2,600 miles away from your dogs, you too will go to the Presidio just to beg dog owners to let you pet their puppies.  Luckily, they oblige.

-  There are a ton of food options here.  It is super pricey, and the lines do get a bit long at the more popular booths.  But it's so relaxed and fun.  Just come with friends to  make the wait less painful.

If you rely on public transit, this is a harder Off the Grid to find, but it's worth it.
author: Amanda J.

description:
This was my first time at Off the Grid: picnic at the presidio. I enjoyed it but I prefer Off the Grid: Fort Mason better. I enjoyed the company of my friends and family, the beautiful scenery along the water, the concept of sunday funday picnic at the park with gourmet food, the weather was a bit windy but I didn't quite enjoy the food as much as I had hoped. 

First of all, i didn't know this event has more gourmet restaurants than regular food truck that we usually see. I was hoping to get my usuals like curry up now, sisig burrito, chairman bao, or bacon truck... however, they were nowhere to be found. The only familiar one was the creme brulet cart and the whole beast. Well, that was a bit disappointing for me... They also don't have as many food choices as OTG Fort mason. The food here is a bit pricey - 12 dollars for a lobster roll which was gone in 3 bites, 10 dollars for a single grass-fed lamb burger with no sides, 16 dollars for fried chicken (4 pieces)...

The food we got were pretty good. 
1. The grass fed lamb burger is super juicy - with feta cheese, wild arugula and pickled onions. It was a bit salty but very delicious (It's restaurant quality).
2. The "sausage" pizza - gourmet pizza that was made on the spot (imagine the line...we waited for a decent 30 mins) was pretty popular. 14 dollars for 4 pieces. the dough was extremely soft and thin. good flavor. kind of stingy on the sausages and basil.
3. Fried chicken - great seasoning, juicy and tender except a bit over priced! 16 dollars for 4 pieces.
4. lobster roll - delicious but gone too soon... 12 dollars
5. baby back ribs from the whole beast - tender and great flavor (not sure about the price)

It is a great space for such a fun event. Personally, I think it's more than enough to add on a live performance of some sort like how fort mason does it. It will add more fun to the ambiance and bring the light out of some "still-drunk, hungover" people.

I think there's a lot more room to improve. Will I come here again? Yes. I still had a lot of fun. It is definitely a spot to hang out on sundays. Maybe I'm just very picky, a very spoiled SF citizen! :P
author: Mindy C.

description: Definitely a great way to spend time eating some good food from a wide variety of vendors. Excellent location in the Presidio. The new Walt Disney Museum is right here too. Great place to people watch too.
author: Steven K.

description:
Do you like food?? Yes, of course you do! That's why you use Yelp! How fun is it to head over to the Presidio, and sample the vast selection of culinary offerings at Off the Grid: Picnic at the Presidio? Very. 

I fancied myself trying various offerings, and ended up with just enough room for one thing, and something sweet. 

They had a booth setup with mint juleps, and other alcholic beverages. That MInt Julep $_____ kicked my butt! Very strong, but very tasty. My partner had a _____,  $_____ and it was really gross. It tasted like some food.

I had some fried chicken from ____________ which was $_____, and was so hot, crispy, tender, juicy, and popping out with flavor. Awesome, awesome. 

She got some amazing tacos from __________ which were $_______. 

We managed to get the very last Creme Brulee from "The Creme Brulee Cart." It was the Southern Lady which had Chocolate Pecan Creme Brulee with candied pecans and bourbon drizzle. They did an okay job, and it was freaking delicious, but to be honest, it didn't have the firm custard quality regular Creme Brulee has; it was more like some warm creamy pudding. I have a really hard time complaining about warm, creamy pudding. $5.50

There was also this one stand with a thing called "almond crack." It was about $8.00 per bag, but very addictive (like crack). It was just some kind of chocolate almond blend. Crazy good. We weren't crazy for their bacon candies. 

It was cloudy and chilly on this day, so bring a good jacket. The place is full of people on blankets having picnics on the grass. Fun times. 


Happy food trucking!
author: Shane N.

description: Two words - JUST GO!!  Not the cheapest outing with food and drinks, but we don't live near here so it was an awesome treat - empanadas, barbecue, pizza, donuts, drinks YUM!  Amazing relaxed Sunday afternoon!
author: Susan Z.

description:
This is for the THURSDAY OTG.

UGH. I wanted to love this so bad - it's such a cool and unique idea. I should've read reviews and gone to the Sunday version, but I thought this Thursday one would be a good relief from work.  

I came here around 6 and the lines were already packed...which I suppose wasn't TOO much of a surprise...except the lines for EVERY SINGLE TRUCK were ridiculously long.  They had ONE area for alcohol, with beers running out by thetime we were halfway through the line. Before 7. Fail. 

By the time we got our beers, it was around 6:45 (I know), and the lines for the food trucks were just out-of-this-world long. Trucks were out of food and we were in line for 30-40 minutes and went maybe 5 steps...there was no way food would last by the time we got to the front.  

Look, I'm ok with long lines, but these lines were horrible.  Such terrible planning - only 10 trucks for 10k+ people who reserved on Facebook?  You've got to be kidding me.  It was obvious you had to be here by 4 PM to reserve a good spot and actually be in a position to get food. Ridiculous!

I'm hoping they have more trucks/alcohol areas next time - I was out in the freezing cold for almost 2 hours and only got 2 beers.
author: Steph S.

description:
The crown jewel of "Off the Grid" events. 

There are lots of vendors... some in trucks, but most in well labeled tents. Unlike Fort Mason, they've got plenty of comfortable space for you and your friends (or family) on the grass. It's a super kid-friendly scene and last Sunday (Mother's Day) there were tons of families out enjoying the sun and food. It's a dog friendly environment as well (so long as your dog can handle crowds). They even had a small farmers market, where I quickly evaporated $40 on chocolate and mixed nuts. Rosamunde was offering a tasty rabbit and rattlesnake sausage and Namu Gaji had a killer roll. One of the better ways I can think of to spend a lazy Sunday.
author: Jeremy S.

description:
It just doesn't get any better than this.  Experiencing Off the Grid: Picnic at the Presidio breathed fresh air back into my life. The experience was so perfect that it surreal. This was very nice to sit in the grass and vibe with the other attendees at the same time as stuffing yourself silly on a perfect August day on the shores of the San Francisco Bay.  
It was here that I had my first bloody Mary and here that my boyfriend ordered and subsequently devoured a mini creme brulee made with Gold Grahams cereal. The scenery was stunning and the food vendors plentiful and there was ample space to stretch out.
author: Lucretiz C.

description:
This was a great way to start off my sunday. Food in the park; a couple beers, and a perfect view. The food venues are in no way basic and offer a variety of exotic and interesting builds. 
I was disappointed about some of the trucks not being here from last year (cuban truck was incomprehendable).
I do enjoy the location, if you end up getting tired of the sun and no place to sit; there are some great museums lined up and all open. 
The beer guy with the cart was awesome by the way. 
All in all, I had fun.
author: Joseph N.

description:
I absolutely love Picnic on the Presidio.  I have turned many friends and family on to this event and my parents love to drive two hours from their home in Modesto just to meet us for an impromptu picnic by the Bay.  
 As other reviewers have stated: The lines are long.  VERY long.  When it is super busy, we've gotten in the habit of just going somewhere else, because we don't want to deal with the masses.  But, every so often we find the sweet spot of 2:00 p.m. as an arrival time because many of the attendees have already arrived and gotten their food, so the lines tend to be shorter.
 Also, as others have stated, BRING EVERYTHING.  We've gotten this down to a science.  In our garage I house a chest full of Presidio items: Blankets, sunscreen, hats, cups, napkins, plastic utensils, trash bags, hand wipes, etc.  I've ordered nice picnic chairs from Amazon.  I'm now looking into some sort of pop-up tent for shade.  Once you get comfortable, you're set.  
 I came last Sunday (Pride weekend) and the crowd was great.  The DJ was playing awesome 80s-90s music and the crowd was enjoying themselves.  The downside was the massive wind that was so bad we ended up leaving after only an hour there.  :(  But, that isn't Off the Grid's fault and it's just one of those gambles with picnics.  If you can be fluid and expect the unexpected, you'll be fine.

 Oh, I'd also recommend you bring cash.  The WiFi/Internet connections there are shaky, at best, and it doesn't help the lines when you're one of those "I only bring a card" people and find you suddenly can't pay.  Cash helps the vendors and the people behind you.  Bring cash, people!
author: Melissa T.

description:
One of my most favorite productions from OTG. When I heard of the fire pits (I'm a taaaaad bit of a pyro), I about lost my s*!$ in excitement. The vendors and a lovely evening out under the stars, with a group of friends made me nostalgic for childhood camp fires (which I started)... Minus the nasty food inexperienced cooks made in the dark. 
It's like I'm in the city but, not... I just transported all my friends to the camp fire and tents I loved so much from my childhood Girl Scout days AND brought gourmet chefs with me. "Baller" Girl Scout badge -EARNED :p But seriously, go. Wear warm clothes and play "pretend camping" in this amazing city with your friends. Bonus- The pups are welcome too (because, who would leave their dog at home for a camping trip?!) :)
author: Jen H.

description:
The 2013 season for OTG's gourmet picnic on the Presidio Main Post, starts this Sunday April 21 (continues every Sunday, until October 27). See link for the current lineup of vendors. http://offthegridsf.com/picnic

As mentioned in my previous review, unlike other OTG events the food vendors are mostly restaurants.

NEW this year, the organizers have added a farmers market lineup. So u can enjoy brunch and some shopping too. There are 5 less street food vendors compared to last year, but they've added 15 farmers and artisans - with lots of fruits and veggies, plus artisan cheese, chocolates and baked goods.

For those who plan to go to the picnic biking, the Sports Basement tent returns again to offer free bike repairs.

Also, the Presidio Trust is joining the truck lineup with a brand new "Roving Ranger Truck", which distributes free educational info (sorry, no food). The inside features a lounge area, with a built-in mini library and a sound system. Very cool!
author: Luis C.

description:
My friends and I went to this event last night, and we had a great time! We'll definitely be back.

Location/Atmosphere: 5/5. Can't get any better than this location! What an awesome view of the bay, and the Presidio is adorable with all of it's "wait, are we still in San Francisco?" charm. The atmosphere is casual and fun; there were people of all ages at this event. We didn't sit at a cabana or fire pit, but brought our own blankets and chairs to sit on. Although maybe next time, we'll come early and try for a fire pit. 

Service/Lines/Parking: 5/5. Parking was easy, and free. The lines for the food trucks were moving pretty quickly--no complaints there! The event staff were really nice and helpful. The website says "bring cash" but all the vendors we went to accepted credit and debit cards as well.

Food Trucks: 3.5/5. Decent selection, but not a lot of vegetarian, vegan, or gf options. I'm surprised, San Francisco! And some of the options that were "vegetarian" weren't *technically*--e.g. "we fry the okra in the same oil that we fry this chicken in!". Not a huge problem for me, but one of my friends doesn't eat meat, so we had to look around a bit to find her a good option.  Also, we overheard a parent who's child had some sort of fish allergy saying it was hard for her to find something for him to eat. The beer/wine/cocktail tent was great--and had a lot of options. However, the drinks were a bit pricey. $11 for a glass of wine--the selections they were offering were probably around $13/a bottle in the store.  

Overall: I'd definitely go to this again! Next time, we will BYOB. If you're going and have any sort of food restrictions: maybe bring something to eat in case none of the food trucks have anything for you. I'd still recommend going, because the atmosphere is quite fun.
author: Kate T.

description:
I looooooove Off the Grid. The concept is great (they organize food trucks markets and select them), people working for OtG are really nice and helpful.

Off the grid: Picnic at the Presidio is taking place every Sunday from 11 AM to 4 PM from April 21 to October 27 on the Main Post Lawn in the Presidio.

This event is open to everybody: children, dogs, bicycles...
They have restaurants tents, food trucks, farmers, 2 bars (mimosas, beers, bloody Marys...), free bocce ball, yoga and games.

My favorite places are: Go Streatery (Oxtail and Grits: Fall-off-the-bone, braised beef oxtail, gravy over grits, topped with orange zest and chopped parsley), The Whole Beast, Humphry Slocombe (Chocolate Smoked Sea Salt) and Ritual Coffee.

My recommendations:
- Come early! The lane in front of pizzeria Del Popolo starts before the truck open its doors!
- Bring some sunscreen, sunglasses, water and hats! The 1st time I got sunburns. Please be careful if you bring young children! It can be very hot (and it can also be windy).
- Bring a bag to carry the vegetables, fruits and flowers you are going to buy at the produce market (Blue House Farm have really cute bouquets!).
- Use the restrooms situated in the Walt Disney Museum. It's more convenient then the porta potties. They are downstairs.

Also good to know:
- Most of the vendors accept credit card; but some of them don't (example: El Porteno). So, bring cash or use the ATM machine Off the Grid provides. It's next to the Information tent (near Del Popolo's truck).
- If you loose something on the ground (ID, keys, sunglasses), ask OtG staff at the Information tent: usually when people find keys and stuffs, they bring them to this tent.

Enjoy! :D
author: Chloë O.

description:
Headed here for some food of course! We weren't prepared so we didn't have blankets, chairs, tents, nothing. This was a great set up for families and friends to eat & kick it/laid back.

Our favorite food truck is The Lobsta Truck but they weren't going to be here today, Sunday... So we decided to try some new trucks. 

I got my first ever egg Benedict, the "San Fransisco" from Benefict Arnold's. It had crab, avocado, white pepper and I asked for no green onions. It was AMAZING! Made me wish I got the two eggs instead! It was the best, I killed it so fast I couldn't even savor the flavor, lol.

Next we had teriyaki skewers and fried rice balls from .. I forgot the name of the truck but it was Asian something. The teriyaki chicken skewers was really good. Then my boyfriend got garlic noodles from a Vietnamese truck, he said it was good but the noodles was a little dry.
author: Yee W.

description:
During the non-winter days, if my friends from out of town are in San Francisco, I would always bring them to this if they are here on a Sunday. It's a great way to start off the day, and then head to Golden Gate Bridge or Crissy Fields.

My favorites? Cholita Linda, El Porteño, and the Whole Beast. 

Really, you can't go wrong with some good food, a picnic outside on a gorgeous day, and some good music. (And puppies!)
author: Joanne W.

description: Nice area for picnic and food truck items. Bring your own chairs, tables, and kids. Not too many dogs as I think the dogs would do it on the large lawn area and leave a smell / residue even if owners picked it up. How's that for your picnic blanket and kids running barefoot. Parking is currently $7 / day or $1.20 / hour credit card or coins with no change 24 x 7 except Federal holidays.
author: Clifford W.

description: Wow, fantastic street food.  Saw them on Triple D and was able to coincide a couple hikes in the Presidio with an Off the Grid fest on a Thursday evening.  Super friendly and fast service.  The "burger" sandwich (with grilled beef) was super tasty.  The kamikaze fries with kimchee were amazingly good!  I'm so glad I was able to taste their food!
author: Tim L.

description:
So this was my first time at OTG Picnic at Presedio. I've gone to other OTG events, but by far I enjoyed this one the most. It's in a great location in the Presedio. Nice lush green grassy lawn, lots of vendors ( 16 food trucks ) and a farmers market. Parking was pretty easy considering how there was so many people.
The crowd is very paid back and friendly. Family's, dogs, children are abundant and great to see. You get a nice family feel. The lines are long for the food but that's to e expected. A wide variety of different foods to choose from. Mexican, Indian, pizza, fried chicken, ox tail, barbecue, creme brûlée the list goes on. That's what makes OTG picnic at Presedio so much fun. The variety of food and laying down on the grass with music playing makes for a great Sunday in the city.
author: Roger P.

description:
This is a pretty epic Off the Grid, especially on a nice day. 

A good selection of food trucks from Indian, pizza, Korean/Asian fusion, Japanese, southern (? ribs and fried chicken), ice cream and tasty looking sandwiches. Nobody will go hungry at this event. There are a few other stands from chocolate to fresh fruits and vegetables. There are a number of wine and spirits stands - they even pull around wagons filled with mimosa-making ingredients.

There's plenty of room to spread out on the big lawn in front of the Disney Museum, so bring a picnic blanket.

I've only been on cloudy days, so parking wasn't an issue but I would imagine it would be tougher on sunny days.
author: Wendy L.

description:
My family and I had an amazing time at Off the Grid: Picnic at the Presidio.  We arrived about 20 minutes prior to opening so we found plenty of parking and there were no lines at the vendors/trucks so it was awesome! 

We didn't bring a picnic blanket but will definitely bring one the next time we visit. 

It was a cold, foggy day in SF but we absolutely LOVED the view of the Bay.  It was beautiful.  

I loved the music they played and it made for a super relaxing fun day.  I've been a lot of the Off the Grid events and this by far was the best and most relaxing. 
 There were no long lines and people were super friendly.

I loved that I got to try so many different vendors.  Bring cash too because some vendors don't accept cards.  Highly recommend - especially for families with young kids and dogs. 

Such a great time!
author: Christine P.

description: This place is great for families! Dare I call it the "Adult Dolores Park?" No smoke, drum circles or miscellaneous blaring music, just a good old-fashioned town picnic with access to great food, desserts, drinks, restrooms and occasionally fun, local vendors. There's a DJ keeping the music consistent and enjoyable, and a nice person by the receptacles to assist with the compost/recycling/trash enigma. Lots of (paid-$4 or$5) parking, easily accessible by muni, and emboldened by the majestic backdrop of the Golden Gate Bridge and San Francisco Bay, this is a perfect place to spend Sunday afternoon with the family!
author: Laura M.

description: Great vibe. I got there late so please dont make that mistake. I was there around 8:40 and din't know the food trucks shutdown at 9pm. Live music, camp fires, beers and amazing truck food make this place AWESOME!
author: Hector H.

description: Just went here today for my friends birthday. Awesome time and great food. I had a brisket sandwich and some fried chicken with BBQ sauce #yum! Then I had a couple drinks and kicked back hard. Awesome Sunday!
author: Chandler H.

description: My friends and I ended up going to the first off the grid at presidio. I was really looking forward to it since I have never been in this area. When we got there, I was a bit disappointed. At around 2pm all the lines were extremely long. The average wait time was about 45 minutes to an hour for food. I was really surprised that there weren't more food vendors for the opening. We ended up giving up on the food line and just ate the chips that we brought. I would definitely suggest bringing your own food if you're not trying to wait in line. The restroom line for the portable bathrooms took about an hour. Two of the stalls were broken so a ton of girls were waiting in the guys line. Later we found out that the restroom at Walt Disney museum were open. I definitely suggest taking advantage of that instead of the portable bathroom. Overall the vibe was really nice but the lines were just ridiculous.
author: Christina C.

description:
I use to love this: Sunday afternoon, food truck, drinks, sun..
I went today and paid $12 for a small mimosa in a plastic cup. Not worth it anymore for the drinks, just bring your own and enjoy the sun!
author: Alexandre T.

description:
We went here on the fist day of the Picnic. Absolutely loved the setting. Lot of cabanas and fire place. Live band playing, Food trucks parked all over. It was a bright Thursday evening, but very cold weather. Better to get your own blanket and grab a place near the fire place. There was a long queue at all the food trucks. We actually stood in line for two hours just to get burgers. But it was worth the wait. Everyone around was having fun. It will take place every alternate Thursday. I am planning to visit again with more preparation. In fact not a bad idea to get your own drinks and food and sit in the park. If you love dogs, this is your place because lot of people come here with dogs and they too have a lot of fun. The trucks do accept credit card but good to have cash. Ample parking space around.
Reach early to grab a good spot
author: Kunal K.

description: Great truck, got to try the Kimchi Balls and the Chicken KoJa on a Garlic-Rice-Bun, and the atmosphere especially during sunset is just extraordinary.
author: Martin H.

description:
Various food trucks - I had a great kale salad but unfortunately I do not remember the name of the truck. The rest were so and so, at least from my point of view - no real stands out. Drinks are overpriced and hard to get - continuous line and not a big variety.
Ambiance and views are great - people are having a good time and that is what it counts!
author: VIORICA C.

description: It's an awesome place to come on a Sunday! It was my first time going to this particular location and I was impressed. The lines weren't bad at all and the vibe was just great. Being able to sit around for a picnic and watching all the cute dogs was relaxing. I don't remember what we got exactly, but the ribs, lobster roll, and creme brulee were delicious! There's a variety of selections, and they even have alcohol or coffee. The event is well organized with both tents and food trucks along both sides.
author: Maggie W.

description:
The place was great. All the food truck lined up along on one side of the meadow. I thought there may be more than just 8 or so but it was still a good variety. There were mostly food trucks that we had no clue about so it was fun just picking one to line up for. The lines were LONG! at least 40 - 60 minutes wait. Our first stop was a food truck name BobCha. It is this Korean joint that had a mix of the American/Mexican culture. They had rice bowls, fries, tacos, burritos, etc. My friend ordered the bob burrito while I got the kimchi fries. The burrito was not too bad, not that exciting either though. It was basically the korean bulgogi beef plus rice and lettuce but the kimchi fries was DELICIOUS. It had kimchi, bulgogi, their home made hot sauce and melted cheese. It was savory and sweet. The meat + the sauce + the cheese really kicked the night off well. Great starter. Walking around with this big box of fries....people were all "whoa...that looks good" IT WAS YUMZZZZ.

Today was a bit windy so it started up kind of chilly already. But whoa...as the night went on and the sun started to set, it just started to get freezing cold. Being in such open space, I would expect Off The Grid to have outside heat stands. I've been to the OTG in Fort Mason and they have live music and heat stands. I had similar expectations for the Twilight tonight but there was none. No heater, no music, and sadly not enough lightings! This is a disappointment because the banner on their website showed a lot of tents and lights and it felt so warm and bright. Really wish there was some music at least. 

Eventually, we got so cold that we had to leave lol. Definitely an interesting area though. Maybe it is just be but I need Music everywhere lmao. So not having music in this OTG made me feel a bit "awwwwwwww" *sad face*
author: Katie P.

description:
There's no way avoiding Off The Grid on Sundays when I work nearby. When I get to work, I see them setting up and by lunch time, I can grab some food. Some vendors are pricier than others but there's definitely food and desserts for everyone's taste.

The only food truck I've tried that has visited Off The Grid is Del Popolo! Their pizza is delicious but I'm a sucker for pizza. I tried their Margherita pizza and it's awesome for how it's made.

I've tried other food vendors like Grilled Cheez Guy, Firetrail Pizza, Peter's Kettle Corn, and Cochon Volant BBQ. 

Grilled Cheez Guy's "spicy" grilled cheese sandwich was decent. It wasn't as flavorful as I thought it would be. Firetrail Pizza is similar to Del Popolo where they bake your pizza on the spot. Peter's Kettle Corn's popcorn is delicious if you're into it. I typically choose kettle popcorn over butter popcorn, if you've never tried it--you're crazy. As for Cochon Volant, it's yummy. A friend has tried their BBQ Parfait and enjoyed it. I've tried their BBQ sandwich which I wish I had gotten more of their sauce because it tasted a little dry. They're known for their sauce so it's okay to ask for more BBQ sauce.
author: Jessica R.

description: This a great way to spend time outdoors with family or friends on a sunny Sunday afternoon in the city.  Bring a blanket, grab a spot on the green lawn with a spectacular view of the Bay.  Hungry or thirsty? Not to fret, there are over 25 food trucks and local farmers selling delic'sh cuisines from all over the world. If you're feeling lazy and hate standing in lines, they even have folks walking around with bloody mary and mimosas kits to make your day!  It's kid and dog friendly too.
author: Zaina O.

description:
What's not to love?
Every craving can be satisfied! Food you didn't even know you wanted to try is there!
Beautiful setting. Throw down a blanket, set up some chairs & a perfect day awaits.
author: amanda e.

description:
The nicest thing about this place is that there's a booth with a DJ playing music, if a tad too loud enough to awaken the dead at the nearby military cemetery.
Lots of families with little kids hanging on the green grassy lawn. Wait, don't we have a drought?  Why does the Presidio Trust get to water their lawn?

There is parking available but if you arrive after 12PM, the cars are driving around like sharks, not obeying the "pedestrians have the right of way".  A stupid SUV driver tried to run us over twice while we were at the CROSSWALK" because he was too impatient trying to beat out another car to a parking space.  Even on Sundays, you have to pay for parking there. 

There are not that many food trucks (lined up on one side) vs. restaurant tents (on the other side).  I've noticed that the prices of the food are now more expensive than what you'd pay at a sit down restaurant.  Hubby got Indian cuisine for $9 and it didn't taste that good.  Have had better from the pre-prepared/packaged Indian food in the refrigerated section sold at Costco!
We went to the longest line - Green Cyclo.  Still their garlic noodles with Mary's chicken came to $11.  We got 2 of those and an extra order of garlic noodles for Hubby and it came to $28 for a total of $37 to feed 3 of us.  I could have had more food at a local Chinese restaurant with leftovers for lunch the next day.  

The food at Green Cyclo is always good.  Saw a banh mi sandwich go by and it looked good.  But at $7, and when I boughr Jr. Yelper one of those sandwiches on Irving Street which had more meat in it yesterday for under $5, you feel ripped off.
And, there's no big overhead rental space that these food trucks have to pay.  
I know it's Mary's chicken and all that but still.... 
I think these food trucks realize that the wealthy hipsters and techies in SF are willing to pay the prices, so they charge as much as the market will bear.  

The most eye popping pricing was the fried chicken tent serving 8 pieces for $28!!
I can fry my own TWO whole chickens for that price.  I know some of the local restaurants are hurting from the food trucks and I think if these trucks continue to overprice, I'd rather take my business to the restaurants.
author: Ry T.

description:
Located in the Presidio on the Main Post Lawn, this market is at a beautiful location. There's generally a lot of parking since you have to pay everyday except certain holidays: $1.20/hr or $7 for all day. Apparently OTG partnered with the Good Food Awards to add to the truck & tent line-up where they rotate 5-10 Good Food Awards members and winners every couple months through the Presidio Picnic season. There's a DJ for music and even a small tent where you can rent small sports equipment to play (i.e. Frisbees, footballs, soccer balls, etc).

Been wanting to go to this OTG market since they opened but hadn't had the chance to till this past Sunday. Nice sunny day, I wanted to go to the Yoda Fountain and then trek around the Presidio a bit so we opted to go to lunch here to save time.

Vendor Lineup on 10/26/2014
Cholita Linda (Tent)
Chotto (Tent)
Cochon Volant (Tent)
Del Popolo (Truck)
El Porteno (Tent)
Fine and Rare (Tent)
Fins on the Hoof (Truck)
Go Streatery (Truck)
Grilled Cheez Guy (Tent)
Kama Food Lab (Tent)
Kasa Indian (Truck)
Little Green Cyclo (Truck)
Mendocino Gluten-Free Baking Company (Tent)
Nopalito (Tent)
Nosh This (Tent)
Peter's Kettle Corn (Tent)
Rosamunde (Tent)
SAJJ (Truck)
Sugarfoot Grits (Tent)
Sweetdragon Baking Company (Tent)
The Creme Brûlée Cart (Tent)
Three Twins (Tent)
Wing Wings (Tent)
The Whole Beast (Tent)
Yerena Farms (Tent)

Alcoholic Drink Tent:
Beer Kit: 5 bottles of beer
Mimosa Kit: Bottle of Cava, pint of juice (orange or papaya)
Bloody Mary Kit for 5 drinks, jar of artisanal pickles, hot sauce and ice
Picnic Specialty Drink: Frozen Mimosas

Our Orders:
Sweetdragon Baking Company: ($6/bag) Pumpkin Ale Brittle and Day at the Park Brittle
The Whole Beast: Halloween Salad ($5); and Pulled Pork Sandwich ($12)
Cholita Linda: ($8) 2 Fish Tacos
The Creme Brûlée Cart: Meow Meow ($5) Vanilla Custard topped with Caramel Drizzle and cookies

We came fairly late (around 2:30PM) so many of the vendors were sold out. As we were walking around trying to figure out what to eat, we sampled Sweetdragon's Brittle and ended up buying two since we enjoyed them. The Halloween Salad from The Whole Beast was interesting and tasted very healthy. The Pulled Pork Sandwich was topped with a cinnamon slaw which definitely went along the Halloween theme. Cholita Linda's fish tacos were amazing. The fish wasn't overly battered and there was a good ratio of fish to filling. As to the creme brulee, luckily we were sharing because it was super sweet. I could barely finish half!

Definitely would come back as it's a great way to enjoy the outdoors. Next time, hopefully my BF wakes up earlier.. ^^;;
author: Kitty K.

description:
*DJ, Food Trucks, Long lines, Great Views*

Probably my new fave Off the Grid spot.  

Bring a blanket and lay in the grass.  Enjoy the views of the bay and partial GG bridge.

Parking $1.20 an hour and limited.

Definitely recommend.
author: Rimi K.

description:
We went on 6/14/15 with our two boys, age 14 and 6. Our 6 year old had a baseball game that morning so we didn't get there until 2pm. We were still able to find parking and plenty of space to pitch our shade tent. We came from Woodland where it was in the 90's and in our rush to get to the picnic, forgot to pack sweaters/light jackets. It was in the 60's in SF and windy so that took away from the experience.

Since we also got there closer to closing time (which is 4pm), some of the vendors ran out of their popular dishes.  I only had enough time to wait in one line so I went to the Green Cycle and got the vermicelli noodle with beef and the Bahn Mi sandwich with beef. Both items came up to $27 which I though was quite expensive. The beef was a little chewy for a sandwich meat but it was seasoned well.

Tips from other Yelp reviewers recommend to bring your own drinks and alcohol to cut back on cost. We packed a small cooler with bottled water, juice boxes, and a couple bottle of wine. 

We will definitely come back another Sunday but come early so that we can try some of the foods that we didn't get to.
author: Marissa B.

description:
ABSOLUTELY BEAUTIFUL LOCATION! 360 degrees just beautiful!

Food was good, even had great coffee.

Large area for lots of people.

Our 8 month old son and 7 year old dog felt welcome too!

Music was great.

Prices are reasonable considering it's San Francisco!!

The grass is well taken care of.

The walk there from Chrissy field is an easy 10-15 minutes (we cut through starting on Divisadero). 

I guess the only thing I'd recommend to make it perfect was to organize the groups of foods together. Or have larger signs indicating what the food items are on the bigger signs above the tents. There is chalk boards everywhere and you have to really look around to see what place serves what. 

Overall, this is a GREAT SUNDAY activity! We will definitely visit again!!
author: Elease A.

description: My kind of Sunday funday! Food tents and trucks and a pop up bar all set in the gorgeous presidio is a good time!  Although it tends to get packed later on in the day so its best to get there early unless you want to stand in a 30 minute line for Del Poppolo which is not a good time. There's lots of food choices so you can eat to your hearts consent all day.  I bring my pop up tent and bottle of wine and hang out, it's a nice way to end the weekend especially if you've been out late the night before.
author: Katrina E.

description: What a beautiful day. Bring some lawn chairs (you'll want them, even if you're a teenager), grab your choice of delicious food from among 30 or so food trucks and booths, and sit back and enjoy the view. The weather cooperated today, the dogs were out in full force and so were the babies. It's just a really lovely spot in a world-class location. We stayed for four hours with no cocktails and it didn't seem all that long. Lovely. I'm an hour away but would love to return again and again. I paid $7 for all-day parking a few steps away, although I'm not sure it was actually required since it was Sunday. There were plenty of port-a-potties - no lines. Very convenient.
author: Leslie D.

description: Fun family day! Great food! love the gelato truck. It was a bit windy but my son, wife, and dog loves spending  the whole day lounging on the lawn so not a bad Sunday activity. Can't wait to go back next Sunday with a bigger group maybe a sun tent for shade and a stocked cooler
author: Matt F.

description:
Came here a few weeks back when it was still "in season" and it's now one of my new favorite things to do In SF (or will be... come March). 

When the weather's nice, this is the perfect place to spend a Sunday afternoon. Bring a blanket, find a nice spot on the grass and eat/drink until your stomach physically can't hold more. There's a DJ blasting a good mix of tunes, and it's perfect for people watching, taking your dog out, or just soaking in some vitamin D. 

There's a great mix of vendors, offering a variety of delicious food. Is it any cheaper than your favorite brunch spot? Probably not. But you can't beat the atmosphere, and where else can you eat a BBQ pork sandwich and a fish taco simultaneously? I only wish the vendors offered half portions so I could have tried even more. Also, there's a bar serving beer, wine, frozen mimosas (yes). 

My recommendation? When March rolls around, get your butt to Picnic at the Presidio. You won't regret it.
author: Jon S.

description: One of those SF things that I wish I discovered sooner... I was there yesterday w/some friends enjoying the beautiful Bay view, those frozen mimosas, food trucks, and the air show because it was Fleet Week. On a warm Sunday afternoon, this may be the best SF activity to do.
author: Mel G.

description: Date night in the city never got so easy - beautiful scenery, great food, fire pits & cuddly cabanas.  Rotating live music, several food options such as curry, Vietnamese street food, pizza. BBQ, and ice cream though a s'more fixings stand would be a welcome addition - also a movie night could work in this venue.
author: Donna W.

description:
I finally made it to OTG picnic! I've been meaning to try out the Presidio's Sunday Off the Grid, but I'm often away on the weekends and just hadn't had the chance (plus kept forgetting). But this Sunday I didn't feel like leaving the city, and a few friends and I did an urban hike from the Haight to OTG. 

It was a beautifully sunny day, until we got our food and sat down. Then the clouds/fog rolled in and I was freezing. Of course, on the walk home, the sun was out again. Oh SF.

But anyway, now on to the important stuff. I really like this Off the Grid simply because there's so many options! There's a few of the usual suspects (ie. food trucks) but then there's also a bunch of tents set up where local restaurants sell their food as well. For example, I got the pork tamales from Nopalito's tent and they were great. When I ordered them, I actually didn't realize there was pork inside (and I don't typically eat pork). But once in my hands, they looked so great I ate them anyway - and wasn't disappointed! I also got an amazing kale salad from The Whole Beast - it had this lovely creamy dressing and was topped with whole peanuts. I usually don't like kale either, but this salad totally changed my opinion! Definitely a day for firsts :)

The picnic aspect is appealing too. At most OTG locations (like the one near my apartment in the Haight) there isn't enough seating and you end up standing around, trying to hold a drink and eat at the same time, and the venture usually ends with food on the ground or on the shirt. You also end up very cold, because it's in the evening, and we all know that SF is incapable of serving up a balmy night.

But here, you just bring along your blanket and voila, more seating space than could ever be filled! And sunshine! (Well, if you're lucky). But beware, there is a plethora of small children, strollers and dogs. So if that ain't your thing, watch out. 

Oh, and they also have a row of port-a-potties which were very clean. Good job OTG!
author: Lindsey B.

description:
Great way to spend a Sunday Afternoon. 
Clean, Music, lots of food options.
